subsection.heading: 1 Introduction: long-distance reflexives and Universal Grammar
subsection.p: A distribution of anaphoric elements roughly like that found in English occurs in languages around the world: there are certain lexical items that occur only with antecedents which c-command them and which are located in the same local domain (roughly, clause) as the anaphoric elements. In contrast, other anaphoric elements are unable to take c-commanding antecedents within the local domain. The fact that so many genetically unrelated, areally separated, and typologically dissimilar languages have anaphoric elements that conform to the same distributional restrictions constitutes convincing support for the view that Binding is determined by principles of Universal Grammar.

While a universalist approach to Binding has a strong foundation in the typology of anaphoric forms, it is also well known that there are many languages in which some forms that can be used as local reflexives can also take antecedents outside their local domain (hereafter, long-distance reflexives). For instance in Chinese, the reflexive ziji in (1) can be interpreted as referring to the matrix subject, the intermediate subject, or the lowest subject:

(1)
Zhangsani
renwei Lisij
zhidao Wangwuk
xihuan zijii/j/k.
Zhangsan think Lisi know Wangwu like self
‘Zhangsan thinks Lisi knows Wangwu likes self.’

Are these ‘exceptions’ to Binding Theory arbitrary (thereby seriously undercutting the universality of Binding Theory and leaving unexplained why so many anaphoric forms in unrelated languages show the same distribution), or do the violations of Binding Theory occur in a restricted domain, due, perhaps, to the interaction of the Binding Theory with other modules of grammar and with extra-grammatical principles governing pragmatics and discourse?

In the sections which follow, we shall examine the extent to which the distribution of long-distance reflexives is arbitrary and varies freely from language to language, and the extent to which the facts follow a similar pattern in a variety of genetically, areally, and typologically unrelated languages. Special attention will be paid to the properties of long-distance reflexives in Asian languages, especially Chinese and Malay/Indonesian. The task of determining the patterns that occur is complicated by the complex relations between syntax and discourse observed with long-distance reflexives. Thus, we devote considerable attention to the issue of which facts are syntactic in nature and which are due to discourse.

In addition to describing the cross-linguistic patterns that require explanation, we consider the adequacy of various theories of long-distance reflexives in accounting for these patterns. Our ultimate conclusion will be that long-distance reflexives are not a unitary phenomenon with a unitary analysis. However, while there is a variety of types of ‘reflexives’ that can take non-local antecedents, one type, which we shall call ‘bound anaphor long-distance reflexives’, displays the typological properties that have been widely identified with long-distance reflexives in the literature. We shall show that, while the discourse properties associated with these forms vary considerably, the syntactic properties (in the strict sense of ‘syntactic’) appear to be subject to much less variation. We argue that the pattern observed can best be accounted for by one theory of bound anaphor long-distance reflexives, the theory that claims that these forms undergo covert movement to a position close to their ultimate antecedents. There remain, however, problems with the movement analysis that remain as yet unsolved.

subsection.heading: 2 Typological properties of long-distance reflexives
subsection.p: It has often been observed that long-distance reflexives appear to share a number of characteristics across languages (Giorgi 1984; Pica 1987; and many others): 1

p.b: Apparent typological characteristics of long-distance reflexives:

row.entry: Their occurrence is, in many languages, restricted to environments in which the antecedent and reflexive are found in specific domains (i.e., specific types of IPs such as infinitival or subjunctive).

subsection.p: Furthermore, it was noted in the Chinese literature (Y.-H. Huang 1984; Tang 1985, 1989) that long-distance reflexives are subject to a ‘Blocking Effect’: when the subjects of the matrix and the subordinate clauses share features for person, either NP is a possible antecedent for ziji. When, however, the subjects of these clauses differ in person, only the subject of the subordinate clause is a possible antecedent for ziji: the subordinate subject blocks the matrix subject (and any higher subject regardless of person) from anteceding ziji:

(3)
Zhangsani
renwei woj
zhidao Wangwuk
xihuan ziji*i/*j/k.
Zhangsan think I know Wangwu like self
‘Zhangsan thinks I know Wangwu likes self.’

In (3) the presence of third person Wangwu as subject of the lowest clause blocks ziji from referring to either the intermediate subject wo or the main clause subject Zhangsan. 2 No similar restriction was noted in the literature on European languages with long-distance reflexives. This raised the question of how the cross-linguistic variation with respect to the existence of the Blocking Effect should be explained and of whether Blocking correlates with any property of the languages in which it occurs or of the forms that are subject to Blocking, a question to which we shall return below.

In addition to the restrictions just mentioned, which were widely interpreted as syntactic in nature, many authors noted that long-distance reflexives are frequently limited to taking antecedents which are ‘prominent’ in the discourse. The discourse requirements appeared to vary from language to language, to at least some extent, but they could, in most cases, be reduced to what came to be referred to as ‘logophoric’ requirements, by analogy with the system of logophoric pronouns occurring in some African languages. This raised the question of how logophoricity should be related to long-distance reflexives. Are long-distance reflexives simply logophoric pronouns masquerading as reflexives, or is the relationship between logophoricity and long-distance reflexives more complex than simple equivalence?

subsection.heading: 3 The Groningen and Cornell workshops
subsection.p: In order to assess the current state of knowledge and to provide an impetus for further study, a workshop on long-distance anaphors was held by the Department of Linguistics of Groningen University in June of 1987. This workshop resulted in a volume that appeared in 1991 (Koster and Reuland 1991). While there was considerable diversity in the interests of the contributors to that volume, two themes preoccupied many of the authors: (i) what is the nature of the domain restriction on long-distance reflexives?; and (ii) what sorts of logophoric or other discourse conditions are necessary for long-distance anaphora? While there was some brief discussion of Asian languages in several of the chapters in the volume, with the exception of the extended discussion of Mandarin in Huang and Tang (1991), nearly all of the detailed analysis was of European languages. This, of course, reflected the fact that in the 1980s most of the research on long-distance anaphora had been on European languages (especially Italian and Scandinavian languages).

Since the appearance of the Groningen volume, there has been an explosion of interest in long-distance anaphora. A workshop similar to the Groningen one was organized by the authors of this chapter at the Cornell LSA Linguistic Institute in July of 1997, in part to assess progress over the previous ten years. The contributions to the Cornell workshop provided the basis for most of the chapters in Cole et al. (2001a). How did the results of the Cornell workshop differ from those of ten years earlier? The most obvious difference between the research conducted in the 1980s and that conducted in the 1990s is that the focus of the later research is on the anaphoric systems of languages that had received little or no attention in the literature ten years earlier. While research has continued on European languages, a large body of work on Asian languages, especially Chinese, has appeared. Not surprisingly, the properties of long-distance reflexives found in such a wide variety of languages are considerably more diverse than those that were the focus of research in the 1980s, but, despite the diversity, the major themes of the earlier research are prominent in current research as well.

subsection.heading: 4 Pronoun or bound anaphor?
subsection.p: A fundamental and recurring topic is whether the ‘long-distance reflexives’ in the language under study have the distribution of pronouns or of bound anaphors. Early studies like Giorgi (1984) claimed that they have the properties of bound anaphors. As it turns out, the question is in fact a difficult one. The study of the typological characteristics of long-distance reflexives has been frustrating because every proposed characterization of the construction appears to have many counter-examples. If, however, ‘long-distance reflexives’ are not a single type of morphosyntactic entity, it would not be expected that all long-distance reflexives would have the same properties or the same analysis across languages. In fact, an examination of current research suggests that long-distance reflexives are several distinct sorts of entities, which differ with regard to whether they have the distribution of bound anaphors or of pronouns. 3 If this is correct, it is not surprising that they differ in both syntactic and discourse properties: bound anaphors are generally assumed to require (or strongly favor) a binding relationship with their antecedents, thereby explaining why they require c-commanding antecedents, do not allow extra-sentential antecedents, and require (or strongly favor) sloppy readings in VP ellipsis. In contrast, pronouns are assumed to enter into both binding and coreference relations. Thus, c-command is not required, extra-sentential antecedents are possible, and both strict and sloppy readings are easily available under VP ellipsis.

It may be useful to illustrate the range of variation: inflected reflexives in Turkish (Kornfilt 1997, 2001) provide an example of a form that can be used as a reflexive within the local domain, but which has the distribution of a pronominal when used beyond that domain. Another such example is Malay (Cole and Hermon 1998a, 1998c; Cole et al. 2001b). In these languages apparent long-distance reflexives show none of the characteristics of bound anaphors: outside of the local domain the antecedent does not need to c-command the ‘reflexive’, extra-sentential antecedents are possible, and strict readings are easy to come by under VP ellipsis. This is illustrated from Malay:

(4)
Ahmadi
tahu Salmahj
akan membeli baju untuk dirinyai/j/k.
Ahmad know Salmah will buy clothes for self.3sg
‘Ahmad knows Salmah will buy clothes for him/herself.’

(5)
a. [NP Bapa Sitij]i
tidak suka dirinyai/j/k.
father Siti not like self.3sg
‘Siti's father does not like her/himself/him.’
b. [NP Ibu Alij]i
telah mengenalkan dirinyai/j/k.
mother Ali already introduce self.3sg
‘Ali's mother has introduced him/herself/her to my friends.’

In (4) dirinya can be interpreted either as a local reflexive, as referring to the matrix subject, or as referring to some third individual in the discourse. The examples of (5) show that a c-commanding or non-c-commanding antecedent, or an extra-sentential, discourse antecedent are all possible.
Turning to VP ellipsis, we see that dirinya allows both strict and sloppy readings, even in local contexts, as is expected with a pronoun:

(6)
John nampak dirinya di dalam cermin; Frank pun.
John see self.3sg at inside mirror Frank also
‘John saw himself/him in the mirror and Frank did too.’ (= ‘Frank saw Frank in the mirror’ or ‘Frank saw John in the mirror’)

(7)
Ali cukur dirinya di dalam bilik air; Bill pun.
Ali shave self.3sg at inside bathroom Bill also
‘Ali shaved himself/him in the bathroom. Bill did so too.’ (= ‘Bill shaved Bill’ or ‘Bill shaved Ali’)
To conclude, the relationship between the seeming long-distance reflexive and its antecedent in Malay would appear to be either coreference or Binding, as is the case for personal pronouns. 4

In contrast, in Kannada long-distance reflexives require c-commanding antecedents, cannot take extra-sentential antecedents, and require sloppy readings under VP ellipsis (Amritavalli 2000; Lidz 2001). Similar facts are found in Hindi-Urdu (Davison 2000, 2001). Example (8) illustrates the VP ellipsis facts in Hindi-Urdu (Davison 2000):

(8)
Guatami
[apnee (aapi)-koo caalaak] samajhtaa hai, aur Vikramj
bhiiØ.
Guatam self's self-dat smart consider-Impf is and Vikram also
‘Guatam considers himself smart, and so does Vikram.’ (= ‘Vikram considers Vikram smart’; ≠ ‘Vikram considers Guatam smart’)
In these languages long-distance reflexives have the properties associated with bound anaphors, and, like other bound anaphors, appear to require a binding relationship with antecedents.

The situation is more complex in Icelandic (Reuland 2001; and see chapter 33). In Icelandic the reflexive form sig can occur with long-distance antecedents in both infinitival and subjunctive clauses. However, sig has different properties in each environment: when sig and its antecedent are found within an infinitival clause, sig behaves like a bound anaphor, but when the domain is a subjunctive clause, it behaves like a pronominal. Thus, in some environments sig must be related to its antecedent by Binding while in other environments a relationship of coreference is possible. Finally, in Chinese (both Mandarin and Teochew) the simplex reflexive (ziji in Mandarin, kaki in Teochew) normally shows the distribution of a bound anaphor: The antecedent must c-command (or subcommand) the reflexive, and VP ellipsis yields only (or predominantly) sloppy readings, as in Hindi-Urdu (Cole et al. 2001b; Huang and Liu 2001; as well as earlier works by many authors). However, in limited discourse contexts ziji can take extra-sentential discourse antecedents, as is illustrated in (9), taken from Pollard and Xue (2001): 5

(9)
Zhangsani
zhidao neijian shi yihou hen qifen; Lisij
shuo neixie hua mingming shi zai he zijii/j
zuodui.
Zhangsan know that-CL thing after very angry Lisi say those word obviously is being with self against
‘Zhangsani was very angry when he learned that. By saying those words Lisij was obviously acting against himselfj/himi.’
The Icelandic and Mandarin facts suggest that the same reflexive form can be a bound anaphor in one grammatical and discourse context and a ‘free anaphor’ with pronominal properties in another.
To summarize, there appear to be at least the following types of ‘long-distance reflexives’:

li.p: long distance bound anaphors, which show the distribution of bound variables (illustrated by Chechen/Ingush, Chinese, Hindi-Urdu, Kannada);
forms which are used as reflexives locally and as pronominals non-locally (illustrated by Turkish and Malay);

forms that are ‘primarily’ bound anaphor reflexives, but which can be used non-locally in specific syntactic and discourse contexts (Chinese ‘free anaphors’, Icelandic subjunctives, and long-distance uses of English reflexives: Zribi-Hertz 1989).

subsection.p: If ‘long-distance reflexives’ do in fact display the diversity just claimed, several conclusions follow:

li.p: The distribution and properties of each type of ‘long-distance reflexive’ (anaphor, pronominal, mixed) need to be investigated separately.
The factual contradictions both in and across languages may be resolved by distinguishing properly the various types of ‘long-distance reflexives’.

A major problem in understanding the phenomenon of long-distance anaphora is the determination of the grammatical and discourse conditions that license each type of long-distance anaphor. The successful solution to this problem may provide the basis for the development of a theory or theories of long-distance anaphora with sufficient power to predict the properties of a reflexive from its grammatical and discourse context. We shall return in section 11 to a consideration of what might constitute the basis for such a theory.

subsection.heading: 5.1 Variation among languages and dialects with bound anaphor long-distance reflexives
subsection.p: A second theme in current research is the attempt to characterize the role of discourse/pragmatics vs. syntax in the licensing of long-distance reflexives. While many aspects of the problem remain unclear, many new facts about the relationship of discourse factors and long-distance reflexives have become known. First of all, the role of discourse varies considerably from language to language, and from form to form within some languages. Nichols (2001) shows that Chechen and Ingush exhibit bound anaphor-type long-distance reflexives. In these languages, however, there is no requirement that the antecedent satisfy logophoric or other discourse conditions.

In many other languages, discourse adds restrictions over and above those of the grammar. For instance, Amritavalli (2000) notes that in Kannada (which also exhibits bound anaphor long-distance reflexives) the antecedent for the reflexive tannu must be aware of the state or event described, leading to a preference for the pronoun avannu over the long-distance reflexive tannannu in sentences like (10) (Amritavalli's 119):

(10)
a. ?Sittei→j
tannannuii/*j/*k
kaaNalu bandaaga raaju sattu hoogidda.
Sita self-acc he-acc to see came then Raju was dead
‘?Rajui was dead when Sitaj came to see selfi/*l/*k.’
b. Sittei→j
avanannui
kaaNalu bandaaga raaju sattu hoogidda.
Sita self-acc he-acc to see came then Raju was dead
‘Rajui was dead when Sitaj came to see himi.’

Even within the same language, different dialects and varieties may vary with regard to the discourse properties of long-distance reflexives. For example, Cole et al. (2001b) show that there is considerable variation in the discourse conditions on long-distance reflexives in the Chinese dialects of Singapore. In these dialects (in most contexts), the reflexive has the distribution of a bound anaphor, but the logophoric conditions on Singapore Teochew are much stricter than those on Singapore Mandarin: in Teochew, the antecedent of a long-distance reflexive must be aware that he, himself, is carrying out the action described (a de se requirement), while in Singapore Mandarin, self-awareness on the part of the antecedent is not required. However, weaker ‘PIVOT’ conditions (Sells 1987) hold in both Singapore Mandarin and Singapore Teochew. In a paper on Mandarin as it is spoken in Taiwan, Huang and Liu (2000) claim that a de se requirement constrains the relationship between matrix subject antecedents and object ziji in complement clauses. In contrast, Pollard and Xue (2001: 326) claim that such examples (illustrated by (11)) are not subject to logophoric requirements: 6

(11)
Zhangsani
zhidao Lisij
renwei Wangwuk
zui xihuan zijii/j/k.
Zhangsan know Lisi think Wangwu most like self
‘Zhangsani knows that Lisij thinks that Wangwu likes himself/himi/j most.’

Pollard and Xue claim explicitly with respect to (11) that “the key fact about such cases is that any commanding subject qualifies as the antecedent for ziji on the strength of its syntactic prominence alone” (emphasis ours). We take such apparent factual contradictions among authors writing about Chinese as indicative of the fact that the discourse conditions vary in subtle ways from dialect to dialect, and from speaker to speaker within a single dialect. It would appear that the extent of the variation has not been recognized adequately in the literature.

subsection.heading: 5.2 Absence of logophoric conditions on pronominal long-distance reflexives
subsection.p: A second fact about discourse that emerges from recent work on Chinese is that, while logophoric conditions may (but need not) restrict bound anaphor-type long-distance reflexives, they do not affect pronominal long-distance reflexives. Thus, in Malay ‘long-distance’ dirinya does not require any special perspective or self-awareness (Cole and Hermon 1998a, 1998c; Cole et al. 2001b). Rather, it has the same discourse properties as a personal pronoun. We believe that a similar lack of logophoric restrictions occurs for long distance inflected reflexives in Turkish (as shown by Kornfilt 1997, 2001) as well as for Middle English and Old English pronouns (Keenan 1976a, 2000), which, as discussed in note 4, can also be used for local coreference). Thus, forms that are indeterminate between pronouns and reflexives do not seem to be subject to logophoric conditions.

subsection.heading: 5.3 Logophoric ‘conversion’ of reflexives to pronominals
subsection.p: In contrast to the situation in Malay and Turkish, as well as to that in Chechen/Ingush, Hindi-Urdu, Kannada, etc., in languages like English, and in Icelandic subjunctives, a form which in most environments is exclusively a bound anaphor is given special license by a combination of syntax and discourse to function as a pronominal. As was shown by Reinhart and Reuland (1993 and earlier works) and by Zribi-Hertz (1989), this occurs mostly when a reflexive occurs in a non-argument position (though the syntactic conditions vary greatly from language to language) and when the antecedent satisfies logophoric conditions: 7

(12)
a. Philipi was supposed to be fooling ( . . . ), because Desiree ( . . . ) had undoubtedly explained to them the precise nature of her relationship with himselfi.
(Zribi-Hertz 1989: (43b))
b. But Ruperti was not unduly worried about Peter's opinion of himselfi.
(Zribi-Hertz 1989: (46b))

In the examples in (12) the reflexive occurs in a position in which it is not an argument of the verb. From a discourse perspective, the sentences present the situation as pictured in the mind of the antecedent for the reflexive: the use of the reflexive indicates to the reader that the scenes are being viewed from Philip and Rupert's perspective.
Note that in the case of sentences like (12b) VP ellipsis allows either a strict or a sloppy interpretation: 8
(13) Ruperti was not unduly worried about Peter's opinion of himselfi; nor was Fredj.
The elliptical clause of (13) can be understood to mean either (14) or (15):
(14) Nor was Fred unduly worried about Peter's opinion of Rupert. (strict reading)
(15) Nor was Fred unduly worried about Peter's opinion of Fred. (sloppy reading)
The fact that both strict and sloppy interpretations are easily available shows that in English, as in Icelandic, the reflexive form has taken on the referential properties of a pronoun.

Although the reflexives show the distribution of a pronoun in both Malay and English, the use of reflexives differs in an important way. In English and in Icelandic subjunctives, as discussed by Reuland (2001), a reflexive can only be used as a pronominal in the specific licensing environments just described, while in Malay, Turkish, etc., no special licensing conditions are necessary. This suggests that the Malay/Turkish and the English/Icelandic cases should not be conflated, and that the English/Icelandic type of long-distance reflexive might usefully be viewed as a reflexive that is ‘converted’ to a pronominal under special syntactic and discourse circumstances, 9 while the Malay/Turkish cases are inherently pronominal (or are indeterminate between an anaphor and a pronominal). (We will discuss and extend Reuland's analysis of the Icelandic facts further in section 11.)

subsection.heading: 6 Logophoric pronouns and logophoric restrictions on long-distance reflexives
subsection.p: We have seen that the various types of long-distance reflexives (bound anaphor, pronominal and ‘de-anaphoric’ pronominal reflexives) differ with regard to whether special discourse conditions apply to their use: bound anaphors may be subject to ‘logophoric’ discourse requirements, but need not be; pronominal (or indeterminate) forms are not subject to these requirements; and ‘converted’ reflexives are (we hypothesize) always subject to such requirements. We would like to turn to an examination of whether the logophoric requirements on long-distance reflexives are the same as those on logophoric pronouns.

The term ‘logophoric pronoun’ was coined by Hagège (1974) to describe a special subgroup of personal pronouns used in reported speech in some African languages to refer to the individual whose speech is reported or to the addressee of that speech. For example, in Mupun, as described by Frajzyngier (1993), there are three sets of personal pronouns as well as a set of reflexive anaphors: 10
In complements of the verb sát ‘say’, pronouns of set A indicate disjoint reference with the subject of the matrix clause:

(18)
wu/wa/mo sát n
wu/wa/mo ta
ee n-jos.
he/she/they say COMP he/she/they stop stay PREP-Jos
‘Hei/shei/theyi said that hej/shej/theyj stopped over in Jos.’
In contrast, the set B pronouns are used in indirect speech to indicate coreference with the matrix subject:

(19)
wu sát n
i n nas an.
3m say COMP 3m FUT beat 1sg
‘Hei said hei will beat me.’
Set C is used to indicate that the pronoun refers to the addressee of the matrix clause. If the reference is to other persons, the pronoun must be drawn from set A:

(20)
a. n-sát n-wur n
wur ji.
1sg-say PREP-3sg COMP 3sg come
‘I told himi that hej should come.’
b. n-sát n-wur n
gwar ji.
1sg-say PREP-3sg COMP 3sg come
‘I told himi that hei should come.’

The logophoric pronouns are used to indicate coreferentiality or disjoint reference with the subject or addressee of superordinate verbs of speaking. Whenever coreference is within the same clause a reflexive pronoun is employed:

(21)
n-seet nl
r n-sen.
1sg-buy shirt PREP-REFL:1sg
‘I bought a shirt for myself.’

(22)
mu-sarep nl
r-mo n-sun.
1pl-buy-pl shirt-pl PREP-REFL:1sg
‘We bought shirts for ourselves.’

(23)
wu cet mbise n-sin.
3m cook food PREP-REFL:3m
‘He cooked for himself.’

To summarize, in a ‘classic’ logophoric system like that described by Frajzyngier for Mupun, logophoricity is a property of pronouns rather than of bound anaphors, and is licensed by whether the matrix verb is a verb of saying: in Mupun, verbs of thinking like pan ‘think, remember’ do not permit set B and C (logophoric) pronouns, but rather require pronouns from set A (non-logophoric):

(24)
wu ben n
wu pan an.
3m think COMP 3m remember 1sg
‘He thinks he remembers me.’

According to Frajzyngier (1993: chapter 20), set A pronouns are required in (24), and can be used to indicate either coreference or disjoint reference. This is unlike the case when the matrix verb is a verb of saying. In that case, the use of a set A pronoun indicates disjoint reference:

(25)
wu sát n
wu nas an.
3m say COMP 3m beat 1sg
‘Hei said that hej beat me.’

According to Frajzyngier, the same pattern obtains with set C pronouns, but examples showing the distinction between verbs of saying and verbs of mental activity like ‘think’ are not provided in the grammar. 11

Logophoric conditions on long-distance reflexives differ in a number of ways from classic logophoric pronominal systems like that illustrated by Mupun. First, as was shown above, the elements in question belong to different grammatical classes. Pronominal long-distance reflexives (like those in Malay and Turkish) are not subject to logophoric requirements. Thus, it cannot be true that when reflexive forms have ‘pronominal’ usage, they become logophoric pronouns. The logophoric requirements appear to be optionally present for bound anaphor long-distance reflexives and obligatorily present for reflexives which have undergone ‘conversion’ to pronominals, as in the case of Icelandic subjunctives and English long-distance reflexives. Second, the discourse restrictions on reflexives are different from those on true logophoric pronouns. The choice of logophoric pronouns is determined by whether the higher verb is a verb of saying and whether the antecedent is the subject of that verb or the addressee. In contrast, long-distance reflexives are typically well-formed when the higher predicate is one of saying or of thinking. While a special set of pronouns (set C) exists in Mupun to indicate coreference with the addressee, no such possibility exists in the case of long-distance reflexives: long-distance reflexives never indicate coreference with the addressee. These facts suggest that the analogy between long-distance reflexives and logophoric pronouns collapses when the two are compared in a fine-grained fashion, and the origin of the discourse conditions on long-distance reflexives is distinct from that of logophoric pronouns. Furthermore, there will be separate sources for the ‘logophoricity’ of bound variable and ‘conversion’ long-distance reflexives. These questions are explored in section 11. To conclude this section, while the term ‘logophoricity’ appears to be too well established to banish it from discussions of long-distance reflexives, it is important to recognize that there is strong evidence against the hypothesis that long-distance reflexives are covert logophoric pronouns. Furthermore, the system of logophoricity found with ‘classic’ logophoric pronouns is quite different from that found with long-distance reflexives of various types. 12

subsection.heading: 7 Logophoricity and attitudes de se
subsection.p: We would like to turn now to the question of whether there appears to be any unified use of the concept of logophoricity with respect to one type of long-distance reflexives: those that are interpreted as bound variables. Sells (1987) claims expressly that the term ‘logophoricity’ has been used for three different though related concepts. Sells's SOURCE is similar to the use of ‘logophor’ in the literature on logophoric pronouns. The SOURCE is the source of speech, e.g., the subject of a higher verb of saying. Sells's second type of logophoricity, SELF, is the individual whose mental state the sentence describes (subject of verbs of thinking), and PIVOT is the center of deixis or perspective for the sentence (the reference point for indexicals). What these notions share is that they refer to the individual whose point of view or general state of consciousness is expressed by the sentence. According to Sells, languages differ with regard to which type of logophoricity licenses long-distance reflexives, though there are claimed to be implicational relations among different types of logophoricity.

In the spirit of Sells (1987), Huang and Liu (2000) attempt a unified treatment of these types of logophoricity in the domain of long-distance reflexives by proposing that the core meaning of logophoricity is SOURCE. This can be extended in some languages to also include SELF and in other languages to PIVOT as well:
(26) SOURCE ⊆ SELF ⊆ PIVOT

Thus, in some languages only SOURCE will license the use of a long-distance reflexive (e.g., with verbs of saying); in others both SOURCE and SELF will license long-distance reflexives (with verbs of saying or verbs of thinking); in yet others PIVOT, in addition to SOURCE and SELF, may also license long-distance reflexives (e.g., with the aid of deictic expressions like ‘come’, ‘go’, ‘here’, ‘there’, etc.).

According to Huang and Liu, the logophoricity condition (being a SOURCE, SELF, or PIVOT as required in a given language) is a necessary but not a sufficient condition for the antecedent of a long-distance reflexive. Thus, as noted by Pollard and Xue (2001), there are instances of SOURCE that do not license long distance ziji in Chinese:

(27)
Zhangsani
cong Lisij
chu tingshuo Wangwuk
bu xihuan zijii/*j/k.
Zhangsan from Lisi place hear Wangwu not like self
‘Zhangsani heard from Lisij that Wangwuk does not like himi/*j/himselfk.’

In (27) Lisi is the SOURCE of communication, but this is not sufficient to permit the use of long-distance ziji. According to Huang and Liu, the relation of a long-distance reflexive to its antecedent is mediated through a structure of predication which normally requires the reflexive to be c-commanded by the antecedent. In (27) the SOURCE Lisi does not license the long-distance ziji because it does not stand in a predication relation with a suitable predicate that includes the reflexive.

The range of cross-linguistic variations allowed for under (26) is illustrated by the two Chinese dialects presented in Cole et al. (2001b). Cole et al. show that whereas in the Teochew dialect spoken in Singapore, the long-distance ziji requires its antecedent to be SOURCE or SELF, in the Mandarin spoken in the same city, PIVOT alone may license long-distance reflexives.

Huang and Liu try to unify the various types of logophoricity by taking them to represent a progressive liberation of the notion of ‘core logophoricity’ – SELF being an extended (or ‘virtual’) SOURCE, and PIVOT being an extended (or ‘virtual’) SELF. This view they share, in part, with Cole et al. (2001b), and with Pan (2001). All these authors explore the possibility that SOURCE and SELF (and for Huang and Liu, also PIVOT) can be reduced to the notion of de se. Developing an idea suggested by Chierchia (1989) for Italian, Huang and Liu note that the restriction on ziji in the variety of Mandarin they report on is not merely that the antecedent for ziji must be the SOURCE of communication, or the individual whose mind the sentence describes (SELF), but, rather, that there is a stronger requirement: the individual in question must be aware that the sentence is a description of an event in which he himself or she herself is a protagonist (a de se restriction), or more precisely, that the individual actually ascribes, or is disposed to ascribe, to himself or herself the property denoted by the predicate containing the reflexive. Following Chierchia, the de se restriction is taken to be applicable to long-distance reflexives generally. For instance, Chierchia examines the distinction between long-distance reflexives and pronouns in Italian, and notes that sentence (28) is a contradiction, while (29) is not:

(28)
Pavarotti crede che i propri
pantaloni siano in fiamme. Ma non si e’ accorto che i pantaloni sono i propri.
Pavarotti believes that the self pants are in flame but not realize that the pants are the own
‘Pavarotti believes that self's pants are on fire, but he hasn't realized that the pants are his own.’

(29)
Pavarotti crede che i suoi
pantaloni siano in fiamme. Ma non si e’ accorto che i pantaloni sono i propri.
Pavarotti believes that the his pants are in flame but not realize that the pants are the own
‘Pavarotti believes that self's pants are on fire, but he hasn't realized that the pants are his own.’

The contradictoriness of (28) disappears when the personal pronoun suoi is substituted for proprio. That is, the use of the long-distance reflexive proprio requires that Pavarotti realize that it is his own pants that are on fire. No such requirement holds for the personal pronoun suoi: in (29) Pavarotti must realize of a certain individual that the individual's pants are on fire. It is not necessary, however, that Pavarotti identify that individual with himself. A de se restriction similar to (28) applies in Mandarin, as discussed by Huang and Liu (2000) and by Pan (2001), as well as in Teochew, discussed by Cole et al. (2001b).

The existence of a de se restriction in Italian and in certain Chinese dialects suggests that neither SOURCE nor SELF adequately characterizes the discourse requirement in these languages. Rather, an apparent SOURCE/SELF discourse restriction may in fact be an artifact of a stronger de se requirement. While languages differ with respect to whether bound anaphor long-distance reflexives are subject to a de se restriction, the presence of such a restriction may explain instances of apparent SOURCE/SELF restrictions in languages in which they occur. We shall return to the origin of de se below.

subsection.heading: 8 The dividing line between local and long-distance reflexives
subsection.p: We will turn now to a new topic, one which figures in much current research on reflexives. It is taken as given in discussions of long-distance reflexives that there is a well-defined notion of what constitutes a local reflexive and what anaphoric relations are nonlocal. There are in fact two widely held notions of locality in the generative literature on reflexives. The traditional Binding Theory (Chomsky 1981 and subsequent works) treats the local domain (‘governing category’) as, roughly, consisting of the clause plus the subject of a non-finite complement clause. In a departure from the Chomskyan approach, Reinhart and Reuland (1993 and earlier work) have argued that the core use of reflexives is to mark co-argumenthood, not intra-clausal coreference. 13 Thus, the expected division would be between anaphors used to mark co-argumenthood and other anaphors, rather than between clause-internal (or governing-category-internal) and clause-external (or governing-category-external) anaphora. Reinhart and Reuland's proposal is provided immediate support by the fact that many Germanic languages distinguish between different anaphoric forms along the lines predicted by Reinhart and Reuland's theory. For example, in Dutch zichzelf ‘himself’ is restricted to co-argument positions: 14

(30)
Max haat zichzelf.
Max hates self-self
‘Max hates himself.’

(31)
*Max haat zich.
Max hates self
‘Max hates himself.’

(32)
Max hoorde mij over zich praten.
Max heard me about self talk
‘Max heard me talk about him.’

(33)
*Max hoorde mij over zichzelf praten.
Max heard me about self talk
‘Max heard me talk about him.’

(34)
Jani
zag Pietj
de spullen naast zichi/*zichzelfi
neerlegen.
Jan saw Piet the gear next.to self self-self
‘Jan saw Piet put the gear next to him.’

Examples (30–34) show that the ‘true reflexive’ zichzelf ‘himself’ is restricted to co-arguments, while the ‘pronominal reflexive’ zich is permitted for both intra-clausal non-co-argument reflexives and long-distance reflexives. Similar facts occur outside Germanic as well. See Lidz (1996, 2001).

While the pattern just illustrated appears to provide prima facie support for Reinhart and Reuland's division of anaphora into co-argument and non-co-argument anaphora, there are purported to be arguments against the definition of locality in terms of co-argumenthood. First, Lidz (2001) argues from Kannada examples much like (30–34) that the distinction between zich- and zichzelf-type anaphors is not a distinction between co-argument and non-co-argument anaphora. Rather, the two types of anaphors differ in meaning. The apparent anti-locality of the zich-type anaphor is due to a distinction between ‘pure reflexivity’ (zich-type) and ‘near reflexivity’ (zichzelf-type). Lidz argues that pure reflexives are compatible only with inherently reflexive predicates or with predicates that have been marked as reflexive by a verbal reflexive marker (as in Kannada). Thus, zich-type reflexives are predicted to occur only with reflexive predicates like ‘shave’ or in cases of non-co-arguments, for which the distinction between pure reflexivity and near reflexivity is not relevant. Lidz argues that this semantic distinction removes an apparently strong empirical support for the division between co-argument and non-co-argument anaphora. In evaluating the force of Lidz's arguments, it is not clear that the facts he adduces are not tangential to the issue of the nature of locality. In any case, Lidz provides additional evidence that the distinction between zich-type and zichzelf-type anaphors is not devoid of semantic content.

The question of whether the dividing line between local and non-local should be the governing category or the co-argument/non-co-argument distinction is considered by Hestvik and Philip (2001), who present evidence from Norwegian child language that binding of non-co-arguments within the simple clause (locative PPs and possessive reflexives) constitutes an instance of ‘core Binding’, while Binding into picture NPs is an instance of ‘logophoric’ Binding. Thus, on the assumption that ‘core Binding’ is equivalent to the local domain, from the perspective of child language the local domain appears to include non-co-arguments within the simple clause. A similar point is made by Huang and Liu (2001), who show that ‘local’ reflexives in Mandarin are not subject to any logophoric restrictions (neither de se requirements nor PIVOT-related restrictions like the Blocking Effect). What counts as ‘local’ for this purpose includes not only non-co-arguments like locatives and benefactives, but also reflexives with subcommanding (Tang 1989) rather than c-commanding antecedents in the same clause: in both Mandarin and other Chinese dialects, when the head of a noun phrase is inanimate (and, hence, in Chinese, not a potential antecedent for a reflexive), the specifier of that noun phrase can serve as antecedent for the reflexive:

(35)
Zhangsani
de jiaoao hai-le zijii.
Zhangsan's DE arrogance hurt-ASP self
Zhangsani's arrogance harmed himi.

In (35) the non-co-argument Zhangsan is the antecedent for ziji. There is, however, persuasive evidence that ziji does not need to meet any logophoric restrictions: in (35) the antecedent is neither SOURCE nor SELF. Furthermore, the Blocking Effect is not exhibited:

(36)
Zhangsani
de biaoqing gaosu woj
zijii/*j shi wugude.
Zhangsan DE expression tell me self is innocent
‘Zhangsan's expression tells me that he is innocent.’

Thus, the absence of logophoric effects provides strong reason to believe that the relationship between ziji and its antecedent is local – despite the fact that Zhangsan is not an argument of the same predicate as ziji.

We conclude that there are persuasive arguments that there is a division between local and long-distance reflexives along the lines of the locality domain as defined in Chomsky (1981) and related work: the traditional notion of ‘governing category’. We would emphasize, however, that evidence for the need for the notion ‘governing category’ does not in itself provide evidence against the relevance of co-argumenthood for explaining the distribution of zich- and zichzelf-type reflexives, as proposed by Reinhart and Reuland (1993). Thus, the evidence discussed in this section does not constitute a general argument against the use of co-argumenthood to define one type of locality. It does, however, appear to show that co-argumenthood does not constitute a replacement for the notion of the governing category.

subsection.heading: 9 A more detailed look at the typological properties of long-distance reflexives
subsection.p: We would like to turn now to a review of the status of the typological properties traditionally associated with long-distance reflexives: monomorphemicity, c-command/subject orientation, and the Blocking Effect.

subsection.heading: 9.1 Monomorphemicity
subsection.p: It was noted early in the literature that long-distance reflexives are typically monomorphemic while local reflexives tend to consist of more than one morpheme (Giorgi 1984; Pica 1987):

(37)
Credo [che Marioi
sostenga che tu abbia parlato di sei
e della sua famiglia in TV]]
I-believe that Mario claims that you have spoken of self and of-the his family on TV
‘I believe that Mario claims that you spoke about him and his family on TV.’
(Giorgi 1984)

(38)
Giannii
pensava [che quella casa appartenesse ancora a se stessoi].
Gianni thought that that house belong still to self self
‘Gianni thought that that house still belonged to him.’
(Giorgi 1984)

In (37), from Italian, the monomorphemic reflexive se takes a long-distance antecedent, while in (38) the bimorphemic se stesso is ill-formed with a long-distance antecedent. Similar facts continue to be discovered as new languages are examined. For instance, Davison (2000) summarizes the facts of Hindi-Urdu as follows: “If the simple reflexive [apnee] is contained within a nonfinite embedded clause, it may be coindexed with subject antecedents in higher clauses or with the local subject . . . In a nonfinite clause, the complex reflexive apnee aap and the reciprocal have only a local c-commanding subject antecedent.”

There is, however, a variety of counter-examples to the claim that only simplex reflexives can have long distance interpretations. For instance, the Malay reflexive dirinya consists of two morphemes, diri- and a third person marker -nya. Yet, as was seen above, long-distance interpretations are possible. Similarly, the inflected reflexives kendisi/kendileri in Turkish (Kornfilt 1997, 2001) are clearly bimorphemic, consisting of kendi ‘self’ plus -si ‘third person singular’ or -leri ‘third person plural’. Furthermore, long-distance uses of English reflexives are clearly bimorphemic.

We do not, however, interpret such examples as counter-examples to the generalization regarding the monomorphemicity of long-distance reflexives. Rather, we take examples of this type to show that the generalization that long-distance reflexives are monomorphemic applies only to those long-distance reflexives that are bound anaphors, and not to those that are pronominals. To the best of our knowledge, all bound anaphor long-distance reflexives are monomorphemic. 15

It does not, however, appear to be true that all monomorphemic reflexives are long distance. For example, the German reflexive sich consists of a single morpheme like the Icelandic reflexive sig or the Italian reflexive se. While these forms are all restricted to third person antecedents, there does not appear to be a division into two morphemes, one meaning ‘self’ and the other ‘him’, as is the case for English himself or Malay dirinya. However, German sich is local, while Icelandic sig and Italian se take long-distance antecedents. Thus, monomorphemicity appears to be a necessary but not a sufficient condition for bound anaphor long-distance reflexives.

subsection.heading: 9.2 C-command and subject orientation
subsection.p: We saw earlier that a c-command requirement and subject orientation are restricted to bound anaphor long-distance reflexives. It has been noted in the literature (e.g., Xu 1994; Yu 1996) that there is a variety of apparent counter-examples to subject orientation. Such counter-examples might be taken to indicate that seeming subject orientation has a functional rather than a grammatical explanation. In this section we would like to examine four questions related to this general issue:

li.p: Is subject orientation derivable from logophoric discourse conditions on long-distance reflexives, or does it appear to be a grammatical requirement?
Can subject orientation be reduced to a requirement that (bound anaphor) reflexives refer to the noun phrase with the highest rank on the following thematic hierarchy?
Agent < Experiencer < Theme < Other

In the event that the answer to (ii) is negative, can subject orientation be reduced to the requirement that (bound anaphor) long-distance reflexives refer to the noun phrase with the highest grammatical function on a hierarchy of grammatical functions?
Subject < Direct object < Indirect object < Oblique
In the event that these functional explanations fail, can subject orientation be reduced to c-command?

subsection.p: We shall argue that there is evidence against (i), (ii), and (iii), but that (iv) is consistent with the available evidence, at least if c-command is understood as c-command/subcommand. We shall also examine one type of apparent counter-example to subject orientation: reflexives with experiencer subjects. We shall conclude that the evidence is unclear regarding whether these examples can be reduced to c-command as well, or whether they provide evidence that apparent subject orientation is not grammatical in nature.

The main evidence that subject orientation is not reducible to a discourse requirement is typological. We saw earlier that languages with bound anaphor long-distance reflexives differ regarding whether and which logophoric requirements are respected. Thus, for instance, Chechen and Ingush (Nichols 2001) do not manifest any logophoric requirements. In contrast, in Teochew (Cole et al. 2001b) there are strong logophoric restrictions on the relationship between the reflexive and its antecedent. Despite this striking difference between Chechen/ Ingush and Teochew, both languages manifest subject orientation. A similar point can be made on the basis of the comparison of Singapore Teochew and Mandarin in Cole et al. (2001b, 2004). Although Singapore Mandarin and Teochew differ greatly in the nature of the logophoric requirements found, long-distance reflexives are subject oriented in both cases. Thus, there is no correlation between the existence of subject orientation and logophoric requirements.

We turn next to the question of whether subject orientation could be reduced to the requirement that bound anaphor long-distance reflexives must refer to the noun phrase which is highest on the thematic hierarchy in the domain chosen (as was proposed by Giorgi 1984, inter alia). (We assume that in a multi-clausal structure, the choice of the clause in which the antecedent occurs is independent of the choice of which noun phrase in that clause serves as antecedent.) This hypothesis is given some support by the fact that non-nominative experiencers can serve as antecedents for bound anaphor long-distance reflexives (Giorgi 1984). There is, however, clear evidence that this hypothesis cannot be correct as a general source for subject orientation. With regard to Mandarin, Cole and Wang (1996) show that while objects in postverbal position cannot serve as antecedents for long-distance ziji, preverbal objects are possible antecedents:

(41)
Wangwui
shuo Zhangsanj
zengsong gei Lisik
yipian guanyu zijii/j/*k
de wenzang.
Wangwu says Zhangsan give to Lisi one about self DE article
‘Wangwu says that Zhangsan gave an article about him/himself to Lisi.’

(42)
Zhangsani
yiwei Lisij
hui ba Xiaomingk
dai hui zijii/j/k
de jia.
Zhangsan thought Lisi will BA Xiaoming take self self's DE home
‘Zhangsan thought Lisi would take Xiao Ming back to his home.’

Example (41) shows that ziji cannot refer to Lisi, the postverbal object of zengsong gei ‘give’, but only to the matrix subject, Wangwu, or the complement subject, Zhangsan. In contrast, in (42), in which the theme occurs in preverbal position, ziji can refer to the matrix subject, Zhangsan, the complement subject, Lisi, or the theme, Xiao Ming. The fact that within the domain of the complement clause either the agent or the theme can be the antecedent for ziji shows that ‘subject orientation’ cannot be reduced to a requirement that the antecedent must be the highest noun phrase on the thematic hierarchy.

The same examples provide evidence against the proposal that subject orientation can be reduced to the requirement that the reflexive must refer to the highest noun phrase on a hierarchy of grammatical functions (at least for Mandarin). In (42) the complement subject, Lisi, outranks the complement object, Xiao Ming, on a hierarchy of grammatical functions. Despite that fact, the object is a possible antecedent for ziji.

Turning now to the hypothesis that subject orientation can be reduced to c-command, there appears to be evidence that this is the case. Under current analyses of the ba ‘preverbal object’ construction, ba is a functional head and the ‘object’ of ba is the specifier of the maximal projection which is the complement of ba, as shown in (43) (adapted from Cole and Wang 1996):

(We show the complement of ba as AgrP for the sake of concreteness, but the choice of projections is not relevant to our point here. Another possibility is PREDP.) We shall assume for the moment (i) that TP is the local domain in which Binding is determined; and (ii) that some version of the movement theory of long-distance reflexives applies, under which the reflexive moves to a position in which its antecedent is within the local domain of the reflexive. We shall also, for the moment, assume (iii) that ziji adjoins to the head of AgrP (as in Cole and Wang 1996), though this assumption will be dispensed with shortly:

Given the resulting tree (roughly (44)), c-command alone would predict that the possible antecedents for ziji are the subject (the specifier of Tense/AspectP) or the specifier of AgrP (the noun phrase immediately following ba). Thus, both subject orientation and the failure of subject orientation in examples like (42) can be shown to be predicted from c-command alone if a movement analysis for ziji is assumed. Furthermore, these predictions are not dependent on the assumption that ziji adjoins to the head of AgrP (as is generally assumed in the head-movement analysis). If, instead, it is assumed that ziji adjoins to VP (as in Huang and Liu 2000), the same predictions are made:

Thus, we conclude that the reduction of subject orientation to c-command makes more accurate predictions about the distribution of ziji than does an analysis in which subject orientation is a primitive, at least if a movement analysis of LD reflexives is assumed. (We shall discuss the status of the movement analysis in section 10 below.)

While the reduction of subject orientation to c-command appears to make the right predictions regarding the ba construction in Chinese, examples like (46) appear to be counter-examples to subject orientation both as a primitive and as a by-product of a c-command requirement:

(46)
Zhangsani
dui zijij/j
mei xinxin shi Lisij
hen nanguo.
Zhangsan to self no confidence make Lisi very sad
‘That Zhangsan had no confidence in himself made Lisi sad.’

(47)
Zijij
de xiaohai yige ren qu luxing shi Lisij
hen danzin.
self's DE child alone go travel make Lisi very worried
‘That his own child went traveling alone made Lisi worried.’
In (46) and (47) the antecedent for ziji can be Lisi. The S-structure for such sentences is roughly (48):

As is apparent from the tree, Lisi is not the matrix subject and does not c-command ziji. Thus, both in theories in which subject orientation is taken as a primitive and in those in which subject orientation is reduced to c-command, it is predicted that Lisi is not a possible antecedent for ziji.

While experiencer sentences like (46) and (47) appear to suggest that subject orientation is not one of the core properties of LD reflexives, the fact that apparent counter-examples to subject orientation/c-command are largely restricted to experiencer sentences suggests an alternative approach to the problem: perhaps the LF structure of experiencer constructions differs from the S-structure, and at LF the experiencer c-commands ziji. For example, as long ago as Postal (1970c) it was proposed that experiencers are LF subjects. A similar position was taken by Sung (1990). We conclude that the evidence is not conclusive with respect to whether subject orientation is a syntactic phenomenon. If subject orientation is syntactic in nature, it would appear not to be a primitive of grammar or to be derivable from either the thematic hierarchy or a hierarchy of grammatical relations, but rather to derive from c-command.

subsection.heading: 9.3 The Blocking Effect: typological evidence
subsection.p: The existence of a Blocking Effect based on person has been discussed primarily in the literature on long-distance reflexives in Chinese. The Blocking Effect is illustrated by the contrast between (1) and (3) (repeated here):

(1)
Zhangsani
renwei Lisij
zhiao Wangwuk
xihuan zijii/j/k.
Zhangsan think Lisi know Wangwu like self
‘Zhangsan thinks Lisi knows Wangwu likes self.’

(3)
Zhangsani
renwei woj
zhidao Wangwuk
xihuan ziji*i/*j/k.
Zhangsan think I know Wangwu like self
‘Zhangsan thinks I know Wangwu likes self.’

In (1) the person of the subject of the three clauses is identical (third person). In contrast, in (3) a change in person from the lowest clause (third person) to the intermediate clause (first person) prevents the reflexive from referring to the subject of the intermediate or matrix clause. Although the Blocking Effect was analyzed as syntactic in nature in most early studies of Chinese reflexives (e.g., Battistella 1987; Cole et al. 1990; Sung 1990; Huang and Tang 1991), it was originally noted by Y.-H. Huang (1984), who suggested that Blocking has a functional origin. The controversy regarding Blocking remains unresolved. While there is general agreement that certain instances of Blocking Effect are due, at least in part, to discourse/semantic/pragmatic factors, it remains controversial whether grammatical Blocking also occurs. From a typological perspective, the functional/discourse account does not seem to provide an explanation for the distribution of Blocking across languages: why is the Blocking Effect observed only in some languages (e.g., Chinese and Malayalam) and not in others (e.g., Chechen/Ingush, Kannada, Hindi-Urdu, Icelandic, or Norwegian)? Is there a typological difference in the discourse structure among languages that accounts for the cross-linguistic variations, or is the variation due to a difference in syntax?

There is prima facie evidence that syntax plays a significant role in accounting for the distribution of the Blocking Effect in Chinese. Cole et al. (2001b) and earlier work by Cole and Wang (1996), Cole et al. (1990), and others relate the occurrence of Blocking in Chinese to the fact that Chinese lacks verb agreement. The non-occurrence of Blocking in languages like Italian is related to the occurrence of verb agreement in these languages. This topic is debated in detail in Cole and Wang (1996), Cole et al. (2001b), Huang and Liu (2000), Pollard and Xue (2001), and Pan (2001).

According to the agreement theory of Blocking, languages differ with regard to whether INFL (or the appropriate agreement-bearing node) manifests features of person. All languages have a rule of ‘subject–verb agreement’ which states that spec of IP and I must be non-distinct with respect to phi-features. Chinese (in contrast to Italian) lacks base-generated person feature on INFL. Thus, in most sentences in Chinese spec–head agreement (subject–verb agreement) is vacuous. In contrast, in Italian INFL is base generated with person features, so spec–head agreement will play a major role in determining the grammaticality of sentences.
Structure (49) illustrates how Blocking is achieved by the agreement theory of Blocking: 16
It is assumed that the reflexive ziji can be generated with any person feature. In the case of (49) it is generated as [+3]. The following Feature Percolation Principles are assumed:
(50) The Feature Percolation Principles (FPP):

row.entry: The features of the mother node and the features of the daughter nodes will be identical.
If the features of the daughter nodes conflict, the mother node will have the features of the head node.

subsection.p: No problems arise in IP3. The reflexive adjoins to I. Since I has no base-generated phi-features, the feature [+3] percolates up to I3. Spec–head agreement checking compares the phi-features of I and of the spec of IP. Since they do not differ, IP3 is well-formed and the spec of IP3 is a possible antecedent for ziji. Consider now the consequence of adjunction to I2. The feature [+3] is percolated to I2. In the case of IP2 – unlike IP3 – there is a difference in the phi-features of I2 and the spec of IP2. Thus, movement to I2 results in an ill-formed output. Further movement to I1 would not result in grammaticality. Although there would be no conflicting phi-features at the IP1 level, movement to I1 must be via I2. Thus, the FPP predict correctly the Blocking Effects seen in examples like (3).
The agreement theory of Blocking also predicts that Blocking will not occur in languages manifesting verb agreement, as illustrated by examples like the following from Italian:

(51)
Giannii
suppone che tuj
sia inamorato della propriai/j moglie.
Gianni supposes that you are in love with self's wife
‘Gianni supposes that you are in love with his/your wife.’

In IP2 in Italian, the reflexive bears the feature [+3] but INFL is [+2]. According to the FPP, when there is conflict among the features of the daughters ([+3] and [+2]), the features of the head ([+2]) percolate up to the mother node (the higher INFL node). Thus, INFL is [+2], and agrees with the subject of the clause, and the sentence is well-formed. As a result, no Blocking Effect is found when INFL is generated with person features, i.e., in a language in which even vestigial agreement is found.

The Chinese facts and the agreement theory of Blocking will be discussed in greater detail in section 10, where we compare the relative adequacy of different theories of long-distance reflexives. We also defer until section 10 the question of which nominals can be blockers; i.e., is it the case that all and only potential antecedents for long-distance reflexives constitute potential blockers? In this section our discussion will be limited to the typology of the Blocking Effect. The distribution of Blocking across languages provides support for the claim that Blocking is (in part) a grammatical (agreement-based) phenomenon, and is not due entirely to discourse.

As was seen, the agreement analysis of Blocking makes the typological prediction that Blocking will occur only in languages that lack even vestigial verb agreement (i.e., person features on INFL). This prediction is corroborated by Chinese languages, which lack agreement and manifest Blocking. It is also corroborated by Hindi-Urdu, Icelandic, and Italian, which have verb agreement and, as predicted, lack Blocking. Furthermore, strong support is provided by the Dravidian languages: in a comparison of Kannada (Amritavalli 2000; Lidz 1996, 2001) and Malayalam (Jayaseelan 2000), it is shown that the facts regarding long-distance reflexives in these two languages are very similar except that Malayalam has lost verb agreement. As predicted by the agreement theory of Blocking, Malayalam manifests a Blocking Effect like that seen in Chinese, while none is found in Kannada or any other Dravidian languages. None of the Dravidian languages, other than Malayalam, has lost verb agreement. Thus, the Dravidian facts provide evidence that the absence of agreement and presence of Blocking in Chinese are not coincidental.

While the Dravidian facts provide corroboration for the agreement theory of Blocking, other languages present problems for the theory. First, the Mainland Scandinavian languages have lost most verb agreement, but long-distance reflexives are not subject to Blocking. This would appear to be a strong counter-example to the agreement theory. This evidence, however, is not as persuasive as might appear. As is pointed out in Sung (1990), the Mainland Scandinavian languages exhibit agreement in predicate adjective constructions: 17
(53) Predicate adjective agreement:

We assume that agreement in predicate adjective constructions is indicative of the presence of person features on INFL, which are then transmitted to the predicate adjective. Thus, the Mainland Scandinavian languages do not appear to constitute a genuine counter-example to the agreement theory of Blocking. There is, furthermore, some indirect evidence that these languages are not completely without agreement, but are rather similar to English in having a reduced agreement system rather than none at all. In general, two classes of languages manifest subject pro-drop: those with rich agreement systems, like Italian, and those entirely without agreement, like Chinese. Languages which have a reduced form of agreement do not allow pro-drop. The Mainland Scandinavian languages lack pro-drop, which suggests that they retain a reduced agreement system like that found in English.
Finally, Korean may constitute an additional language in which verbs do not agree with their subjects, but for which Blocking is absent. 18 However, Korean exhibits honorific agreement:

(54)
atu-nim-i ttokttokha-si-ta.
son-NOMsmart-HON-Decl
‘The son is smart.’

Sentence (54) illustrates obligatory honorific agreement in Korean. As in the case of Mainland Scandinavian predicate adjective agreement, honorific agreement may indicate that abstract agreement features are present on INFL. The presence of such features would be expected to result in the absence of syntactic Blocking in the language. 19

While the apparent counter-examples to the agreement theory of Blocking are less than entirely convincing, it must be recognized that the typological argument in favor of the agreement theory is not as strong as would be desired. So far the only languages that illustrate the correlation between the absence of verb agreement and the Blocking Effect are Chinese and Malayalam. The empirical evaluation of this argument, therefore, must await the examination of additional languages which lack verb agreement and which exhibit bound anaphor long-distance reflexives. Furthermore, even here it is also clear that there are important discourse factors that contribute to the Blocking Effect (see section 10.4.3 below, and Huang and Liu 2000; Cole et al. 2001b), but the typological evidence suggests that it has a syntactic component as well; the evidence is still inconclusive.

subsection.heading: 10 Theories of long-distance reflexives
subsection.p: We will now turn to an examination of the extent to which various theories of long-distance reflexives predict the typological properties of the construction. We shall restrict our discussion in this section to bound anaphor long-distance reflexives. Our purpose is to evaluate the adequacy of several current analyses, and to highlight the analytic problems posed by the construction.

subsection.heading: 10.1 The parameterization of the Binding domain
subsection.p: The earliest generative approach to long-distance reflexives, dating back to the 1980s, was to explain the possibility of non-local antecedents by proposing that languages differ with respect to the definition of the Binding domain (‘governing category’). For instance, in English the Binding domain might be the immediate clause in which the reflexive occurs, while in Chinese it might be the root sentence. These differences in Binding domain were taken to be parameters of Universal Grammar along which languages could vary.

It is immediately apparent from the occurrence of both local and long-distance reflexives in the same language that such a parameterization could not be on a language-by-language basis, since the same language typically contains forms with different Binding domains. For instance, in Chinese, while ziji appears to take the root clause as its Binding domain, the pronoun ta ‘he, she’ has the same Binding domain as its English equivalent:

(55)
Zhangsani
renwei Lisij
zhidao Wangwuk
xihuan tai/j/*k.
Zhangsan think Lisi know Wangwu like him
‘Zhangsan thinks Lisi knows Wangwu likes him.’

If the binding domain for ta were the root sentence, it would be expected that ta could not be bound within the root sentence. Not only is this not the case for Chinese, but we are not aware of any language in which personal pronouns are subject to such a requirement.
Furthermore, in Chinese the root clause is not the domain for all reflexive forms. The complex reflexive ta ziji cannot take a long-distance antecedent:

(56)
Zhangsani
renwei Lisij
zhidao Wangwuk
xihuan taziji*i/*j/k.
Zhangsan think Lisi know Wangwu like himself
‘Zhangsan thinks Lisi knows Wangwu likes himself.’

Thus, the parameterization of the binding domain would have to be different for each anaphoric element, and not for each language (Manzini and Wexler 1987; Wexler and Manzini 1987: the Lexical Parameterization Hypothesis). Additionally, for a variety of reasons, Wexler and Manzini and Manzini and Wexler argue that each parameter must be independent of all other parameters. Otherwise the parameterization will be unlearnable (in the sense of Wexler and Culicover 1980).

The parameterization of the binding domain has been criticized on a variety of bases: as was just noted, the approach fails to predict that across languages the apparent expansion of the Binding domain is restricted to reflexives, and never occurs with pronouns. Thus, there must be something specific to reflexives that allows them to be long distance. An analysis that predicts similar variation in domain range for other anaphoric elements does not make the correct typological predictions. Furthermore, as was noted by a variety of authors (e.g., Safir 1987; Sung 1990; Hermon 1992) this approach appears to be inadequate as a model for the acquisition of reflexives by children. Most serious from our perspective is that the paramaterization of the Binding domain fails to make the correct typological predictions about the typological properties of long-distance reflexives themselves. Under this approach, in order to account for the fact that long-distance reflexives are monomorphemic, subject oriented, and subject to the Blocking Effect (in some languages), it would be necessary to introduce separate parameters for each of these properties of long-distance reflexives. But, in order for the parameters to be learnable, it is necessary that each parameter be independent of the others. That is, the fact that all these properties occur together is not predicted by the analysis. Thus, this parameterization approach fails to predict the core typological properties of long-distance reflexives. Furthermore, if, in a particular language, a stipulation were added – e.g., that long-distance reflexives must be monomorphemic – this requirement would be entirely stipulative, and would not follow in any way from the principles that license the existence of long-distance reflexives. Thus, this analysis predicts that languages could differ with regard to whether each of the core properties of long-distance reflexives will be found in that language. As a result, the parameterization of the Binding domain does not provide an adequate analysis of long-distance reflexives.

subsection.heading: 10.2 Cyclical re-indexing
subsection.p: The first analysis to predict some of the typological properties of long-distance reflexives was that of Tang (1985, 1989), who proposed that long-distance reflexives in Chinese should be accounted for in terms of a process of cyclical re-indexing of the reflexive with potential antecedents. Tang proposed the following hypothesis: long-distance reflexives are not simply reflexives with an expanded Binding domain, but rather the process of extending the domain is cyclic in nature. This hypothesis was suggested by the seemingly cyclic nature of the Blocking Effect. It will be remembered that in Chinese a difference in person features between the subject of the clause containing ziji and a superordinate clause prevents ziji from referring to the subject of the superordinate clause, or any higher clause. That is, all intermediate subjects between ziji and its ultimate antecedent must agree in phi-features. Such a requirement is at least suggestive of the possibility that ziji must be tested for agreement in phi-features with each potential subject along the path to its final antecedent. That is, the process of checking the feature content of ziji against intermediate subjects appears to be cyclic in nature.

Turning to the details of Tang's analysis, this result is achieved in the following way: ziji is analyzed as pro-ziji. The pro element in pro-ziji transfers its phi-features to ziji. The phi-features of ziji are thereby fixed and cannot be changed in the course of the derivation. Ziji with phi-features undergoes an obligatory cyclic indexing process which reassigns to ziji the (referential) index of the potential binder in the Binding domain. In order for the indexing to be well-formed, ziji must agree with the potential antecedent in phi-features. The indexing process applies iteratively, and, presumably, cyclically. Thus, ziji can be assigned the referential index of an antecedent which is separated from its surface position in an unbounded fashion. However, ziji can never be assigned the referential index of a nominal that has phi-features that are different from those of the lowest potential antecedent, nor can the phi-features of intervening potential antecedents differ from those assigned to ziji on the first cycle. Thus, the Blocking Effect is predicted by the cyclic nature of (re-)indexing. 20

Tang's proposal has a number of advantages over the parameterization of the Binding domain. First, it provides an analysis of long-distance reflexives that is specific to reflexives, thereby remedying one of the serious deficiencies of the parameterization of the Binding domain. It will be remembered that domain parameterization predicts the possibility of variation in Binding domains for pronouns as well as for reflexives. Cyclic re-indexing also provides an account of why ziji is long distance but not ta ziji; only pro-ziji, which lacks phi-features, is subject to cyclic re-indexing. Because ta ziji is generated with phi-features, it is assigned an unchangeable referential feature on the first cycle. That is, the critical difference between ziji and ta ziji which makes ziji long distance is taken to be the presence of lexically specified phi-features on ta ziji and their absence on ziji. In addition, cyclic reindexing provides an account of the cyclic nature of Blocking, also an important improvement over previous analyses.

The analysis appears, at least, to fail to predict subject orientation, which is stipulated. Furthermore, the analysis of the distinction between local and long-distance reflexives does not make the correct cross-linguistic predictions: any reflexive with lexically specified phi-features is predicted to be purely local. In Italian, however, both long distance and local reflexives are lexically specified as third person (long distance se and proprio vs. local se stesso). The factor which differentiates between local and long-distance reflexives is not feature content, but whether the form is monomorphemic or complex. Monomorphemic forms (se and proprio) are long distance while the complex form (se stesso) is local. Similar patterns are found in other European languages, so it would seem that the presence or absence of person features is not what differentiates local and long distance, but rather whether the form is simple or complex.

In addition, the analysis provides no explanation of how cyclic re-indexing occurs. From the perspective of contemporary linguistic theory, cyclic re-indexing is implausible as a mechanism: the process of re-indexing is non-local and unbounded, in that it occurs iteratively at ever greater remove from the location of the reflexive, while current expectations would be that both indexation and feature agreement should apply only in a local domain. The absence of a detailed account of the mechanisms by which re-indexing occurs suggests not that the proposal should be abandoned, but that it should be viewed as an incomplete analysis. Cyclic re-indexing might be viewed as a prototype for an analysis of long-distance reflexives, a schema of properties (re-indexing, cyclic application) that a full analysis of long-distance reflexives should possess.

subsection.heading: 10.3 Movement analyses
subsection.p: The possibility of a movement analysis for long-distance reflexives was first suggested by Pica (1987, inter alia), an idea that was later developed by Battistella (1987), Huang and Tang (1988, 1991), Cole et al. (1990), and others for Chinese. 21 The basic idea is that long-distance reflexives are only apparently non-local. Rather, the long-distance reflexive moves successive-cyclically in the LF component from the position where it is generated to a position in which it has a local relationship with its ultimate antecedent:

The movement approach provides a solution to two important problems we noted with respect to the cyclic re-indexing analysis: the absence of a detailed description of the mechanisms involved in re-indexing, and the apparent non-locality of the relationship between the reflexive and its ultimate antecedent. The movement of the reflexive to a position near its ultimate antecedent allows a local account of the co-indexing of the reflexive and its seemingly long-distance antecedent. The seeming long-distance antecedent is in fact an LF-local antecedent. Thus, movement can be viewed as an elaboration of the cyclic re-indexing model earlier proposed by Tang rather than as an entirely new approach.
Several questions arise if a movement approach is adopted:

li.p: What is the nature of the reflexive movement, XP movement (presumably to an A′-position), of the maximal projection containing the reflexive or head movement of the reflexive noun?
To what position does the reflexive move?
What is the motivation of the movement?

subsection.p: In general, analyses have been divided between two approaches: head movement of the reflexive to a functional head, generally INFL or AGR (works by Pica 1987, Battistella 1987, Cole et al. 1990, and others) or adjunction of the reflexive XP to the IP immediately below the antecedent (Huang and Tang 1991; Huang and Liu 2001): 22

In (58) the reflexive noun ziji moves by head movement from the position in which it is originally inserted to the INFL of the clause in which the antecedent occurs. The alternative analysis, in which the XP reflexive adjoins to the IP below its antecedent, is illustrated in (59):

(59) XP adjunction to IP:
23

In (59) the XP ziji moves by successive-cyclic adjunction to IP from the subordinate clause to a position in which it is adjoined to the IP below the clause containing the antecedent. Note that (58) and (59) differ in two ways: the type of movement (head movement vs. XP movement) and the position to which the reflexive moves (a functional projection in the clause containing the antecedent vs. adjunction to the clause below that in which the antecedent occurs). These two points are in fact separable. Thus, while no one has made such a proposal in the literature, a derivation like (60) is possible:

In (60) ziji has moved by head movement to a position roughly equivalent to the position occupied by ziji in (59). Similarly, in (61) the XP containing ziji adjoins to the VP of the clause in which the antecedent for ziji is found:

subsection.heading: 10.4 Relative adequacy of differing approaches to movement
10.4.1 Morphological complexity vs. phi-features
subsection.p: We shall now turn to an examination of the degree to which the various versions of the movement analysis predict the primary typological properties of the construction. First, given certain auxiliary assumptions, head movement (derivation (58) and (60)) predicts that long-distance reflexives will be simplex and local reflexives complex. 24 At least in the case of complement clauses like those illustrated here, we may assume that nothing blocks the movement of the noun ziji from the clause in which it is generated to matrix INFL (in 58) or COMP (in 60). 25 On the assumption that inter-clausal XP movement is only via the specifier of CP, and making the further assumption that movement via specifier of CP is not possible for reflexives (perhaps because this route is restricted to operators and ziji is not an operator), XP reflexives would not be able to move from clause to clause. Thus, it is predicted that only X0 reflexives can be long distance.
