A related but not identical prediction is made by the XP adjunction analysis, again making use of auxiliary assumptions. 26 On the assumption that the property that distinguishes long-distance reflexives from local reflexives is that the former lack phi-features while the latter have them, and making the further assumption that only reflexives without phi-features can be long distance, it would be predicted that only reflexives that are not distinguished for person can be long distance. However, as we saw earlier, while this is a correct characterization of Chinese, it is not in fact generally the case that reflexives with phi-features cannot be long distance. It will be remembered that Chinese ziji, Italian se and proprio, and Icelandic sig are all restricted to third person antecedents. But, despite the fact that they are generated with phi-features, se, proprio, and sig can take long-distance antecedents. Thus, an explanation of the simplex nature of long-distance reflexives as due to the correlation between morphological simplicity and the absence of phi-features may seem to be accidental.

The seeming advantage we see here of X0 movement over XP movement is not absolute, however, as it depends on a battery of auxiliary assumptions, as noted. Alternative assumptions could be made and the argument could be turned around completely. For example, it has been assumed that the bare reflexive zibun in Japanese, ziji in Chinese, and proprio in Italian are operators or operator-bound (see Chierchia 1989; Katada 1991; Huang and Liu 2000), but compound reflexives like karezisin, taziji, and se stesso are not. A similar assumption could be made for se and sig but not their compound XP counterparts. This distinction between X0 and XP reflexives can be attributed to the fact that the XP reflexives contain a pronominal component which makes them ‘definite’ on a par with other pronouns. Such ‘reflexive pronouns’ (as the traditional term implies), like the normal personal pronouns, are not operators. The bare reflexives, being devoid of a pronominal component, are indefinite operators on a par with indefinite quantifiers like somebody, everybody. Now, since operators are subject to A′-XP-movement, and A′-XP-movement is well known for creating (apparent) long-distance dependencies (albeit through successive local movements), the fact that bare, monomorphemic reflexives may have long-distance antecedents simply follows from the typical property of operator movement, under the assumption that they are XP operators undergoing LF A′-movement. On the other hand, it is well known that head movement is much more restricted than XP-A′-movement (due to the Head Movement Constraint (HMC), etc.: see note 25), a head-movement approach to bare reflexives may lead us to expect that it allows only local Binding, contrary to fact.

subsection.heading: 10.4.2 Subject orientation
subsection.p: Turning next to subject orientation, it will be remembered that we argued earlier that subject orientation appears to be reducible to c-command. As shown in section 9.2, subject orientation can be predicted correctly regardless of whether the movement in question is head movement or movement of a maximal projection. What is, however, relevant for the prediction of subject orientation is whether the reflexive moves to a functional projection within the clause containing the ultimate antecedent or whether the movement is adjunction to the IP below the clause containing the ultimate antecedent.
Consider an example like (62), in which both the matrix and the complement subjects are potential antecedents for ziji, but in which the matrix object is not:

(62)
Zhangsani
gausu Lisij
Wangwuk
bu xihuan zijii/*j/k.
Zhangsan told Lisi Wangwu not like self
‘Zhangsan told Lisi that Wangwu does not like him/himself.’
We shall consider two possible derivations for (62). If ziji moves to a functional projection within the matrix clause:
the only potential long-distance antecedent is predicted to be Zhangsan, since Lisi fails to c-command ziji at LF. If the movement of ziji is to a functional projection in the complement clause:

it is predicted that only Wangwu is within the local domain of ziji at LF, thereby yielding the local interpretation. The interpretation in which ziji is co-indexed with Lisi is predicted not to occur because there is no derivation in which Lisi both c-commands ziji and is within the local Binding domain of the reflexive.
In contrast, if ziji adjoins to the complement IP, it is predicted that Zhangsan, Lisi, or Wangwu are potential antecedents: 27

In (65), unlike (63), Lisi c-commands ziji and is within the Binding domain of the reflexive. 28 In fact, this interpretation does not occur, a fact which would appear to provide evidence that ziji must move to a functional position within the clause in which the antecedent occurs rather than adjoin to the complement clause.

This conclusion, however, is again not necessary. For one thing, as just pointed out in connection with (61), the XP-movement theory could require ziji to be adjoined to the matrix VP in (65), where it would not be c-commanded by Lisi, thus deriving subject orientation. Second, as just pointed out in connection with (60), head movement of ziji could land it at C of the complement CP below the matrix verb in (63), where it is c-commanded by Lisi, thus incorrectly allowing an object antecedent. This latter situation also seems unavoidable even if ziji lands finally in the matrix I, since the HMC would require the head to have moved through C0 on its way to matrix I. Assuming the possibility of reconstruction (cf. note 27), the head-movement hypothesis actually does not ensure subject orientation.

The issue of subject orientation is also complicated by the existence of various counter-examples to subject orientation, such as the experiencer constructions discussed in section 9. Thus, it is a matter of controversy whether it is desirable to predict the occurrence of subject orientation. Ultimately, this question will be decided by the consensus that develops regarding the analysis of constructions like the experiencer construction, a topic which is beyond the scope of this chapter.

subsection.heading: 10.4.3 The Blocking Effect
subsection.p: Before it is possible to evaluate how well different approaches to reflexive movement account for the Blocking Effect, it is necessary to give further consideration to what Blocking facts need to be explained and whether the appropriate explanation is grammatical or in terms of discourse/pragmatic principles. We shall first consider some facts from Chinese that show that Blocking is not entirely grammatical in nature. It will be remembered that the agreement theory of Blocking predicted that only subjects should induce Blocking. However, as was first shown by Xu (1993) and Yu (1991), first and second person non-subjects can also induce a Blocking Effect:

(66)
a. Zhangsani
shuo [[nij zuo de chunshi] haile ziji*i/j].
Zhangsan say you do silly deeds harm self.3sg
‘Zhangsan says that the silly things you have done have harmed you.’
b. Zhangsani
shuo [[Lisij zuo de chunshi] haile zijii/j].
Zhangsan say Lisi do silly deeds harm self.3sg
‘Zhansan says that the silly things Lisi has done have harmed him/you.’

In (66a) the subcommanding specifier of the subordinate subject (ni ‘you’) differs in person features from the matrix subject, but the subordinate subject itself (ni zuo de chunshi ‘silly deeds you have done’) does not: both are third person. However, the subcommander prevents the matrix subject from anteceding ziji. In (66b), however, the subcommander and the matrix subject are both third person, and the matrix subject is a possible antecedent for ziji.
Furthermore, going beyond Xu and Yu's examples, at least for many speakers, the Blocking Effect can be induced by a non-c-commanding nominal that is not a possible antecedent for ziji:

(67)
a. Zhangsani
cong nij
nar ting shuo Malik
hen taoyan ziji??i/*j/k.
Zhangsan from you there hear say Mary very hate self
‘Zhangsan heard from you that Mary hates herself.’
b. Zhangsani
cong Lisij
nar ting shuo Malik
hen taoyan zijii/*j/k.
Zhangsan from Lisi there hear say Mary very hate self
‘Zhangsan heard from Lisi that Mary hates herself.’

While neither ni ‘you’ in (67a) nor Lisi in (67b) is a possible antecedent for ziji (since they fail to c-command/subcommand ziji), the fact that ni is second person prevents the matrix subject from anteceding ziji (or, for some speakers, makes it more difficult for the matrix subject to antecede ziji). In contrast, when ni is replaced by a third person nominal (Lisi), it is not problematic for the matrix subject to be the antecedent for ziji.
Reduced felicity is also found when a first or second person pronoun occurs in a position in the sentence which the agreement theory of Blocking would predict to be irrelevant to Blocking:

(68)
a. Zhangsani
zhidao Malij
gen ziji??i/??j
shuoguo ni xiang qu Taiwan.
Zhangsan knows Mary with self said you want go Taiwan
‘Zhangsan knows Mary told him/herself that you want to go to Taiwan.’
b. Zhangsani
zhidao Malij
gen zijii/??j
shuoguo Lisi xiang qu Taiwan.
Zhangsan knows Mary with self said Lisi want go Taiwan
‘Zhangsan knows Mary told him/herself that Lisi want to go to Taiwan.’

The second person nominal in (68a) does not intervene between ziji and its antecedent. Despite this fact, (68a) is less felicitous than (68b), in which ni ‘you’ is replaced by a third person nominal, Lisi. While explanations for (66) are possible in variants of the agreement theory of Blocking, 29 examples like those of (67) and (68) cannot be explained by such an account. These facts suggest that Blocking must have a major discourse component, which can be summarized as below, using the terminology of Sells (1987):

(69) Discourse requirement in Chinese:
a. The antecedent for an LD reflexive must be the internal PIVOT.
b. The presence of a first or second person pronoun anywhere in the sentence constitutes an external PIVOT, which blocks the possibility of an internal PIVOT.

In fact, something more general than (69b) seems to hold: the presence of any distinct PIVOT in a given sentence blocks the possibility of another PIVOT serving as the antecedent of an LD reflexive. The Blocking element can be a PIVOT associated with a first or second person pronoun as illustrated above, or it may be associated with a third person nominal element. For example, in Huang and Liu (2000), it is shown that a third person DP may induce Blocking if it is introduced deictically. In the example below, the pointing finger indicates that the speaker points to the referent of neige ren ‘that person’ in uttering the sentence:

(70)
Zhangsan shuo [
ta qipian-le ziji].
Zhangsan said he/she cheate-Perf self
‘Zhangsan said that he/she cheated himself/herself.’

The reflexive must be bound by ta but not by Zhangsan. This happens because the deictic use of ta establishes it as an (external) PIVOT, thus blocking the possibility of a distinct PIVOT as an LD antecedent of ziji.
Another case of PIVOT-Blocking occurs in sentences with multiple occurrences of ziji. In the example below (from Pan 1997), note that the most deeply embedded clause contains two occurrences of ziji:

(71)
Zhangsan renwei Lisi zhidao [Wangwu ba ziji1
de shu song-gei-le ziji2
de pengyou].
Zhangsan think Lisi know Wangwu BA self's books gave to self's friends
‘Zhangsan thinks that Lisi knows that Wangwu gave self's books to self's friends.’

While both ziji1 and ziji2 may take Zhangsan or Lisi as their long-distance antecedents, the two reflexives may not take separate LD antecedents so that ziji1 refers to Zhangsan while ziji2 refers to Lisi, or vice versa. The sentence cannot mean that Zhangsan thinks that Lisi knows that Wangwu gave Zhangsan's books to Lisi's friends, or that Zhangsan thinks that Lisi knows that Wangwu gave Lisi's books to Zhangsan's friends.

Note that in (71) (as in (70)), all noun phrases involved are in the third person, so agreement cannot play a role in accounting for the Blocking Effect observed. From a discourse perspective, however, a natural explanation is that Blocking again occurs as a result of potential pivotal conflicts. In particular, having Zhangsan as a long-distance antecedent for one occurrence of ziji presupposes its status as an (internal) PIVOT of the sentence, and this prevents Lisi from being also a PIVOT and a potential long-distance antecedent for another occurrence of ziji; and vice versa.
In short, it is clear that Blocking has a discourse component along the lines of (72):
(72) Discourse requirement in Chinese (revised):

row.entry: The antecedent for an LD reflexive must be a PIVOT.
The presence of a PIVOT (external or internal) in a sentence prevents a reflexive from taking any other distinct DP as a long-distance antecedent.

subsection.p: Having made a strong case for the relevance of discourse, a natural question arises: does this mean that Blocking is a purely discourse phenomenon? We think not. First, the typological facts that led to the agreement theory of Blocking are not explained by the discourse theory of Blocking (if the typological facts hold up when more languages are examined). Second, there are facts internal to Chinese that give support to an agreement-based approach, independent of the discourse principle in (72). Cole and Wang (1996) note that while both subjects and the nominals following ba/bei are possible antecedents for LD reflexives (as discussed in section 9.2), subjects create strong Blocking Effects while the nominals following ba/bei do not:

(73)
a. Zhangsani
yiwei woj
hui ba nik
dai hui ziji*i/j/k
de jia.
Zhangsan thought I will BA you take back self 's home
‘Zhangsan thought I would take you back to *his/my/your home.’
b. Zhangsani
yiwei woj
hui bei nik
dai hui ziji*i/j/k
de jia.
Zhangsan thought I will by you take back self 's home
‘Zhangsan thought I would be taken by you back to *his/my/your home.’
c. Zhangsani
yiwei Lisij
hui ba nik
dai hui zijii/j/k
de jia.
Zhangsan thought Lisi will BA you take back self 's home
‘Zhangsan thought Lisi would take you back to his/my/your home.’
d. Zhangsani
yiwei Lisij
hui bei nik
dai hui zijii/j/k
de jia.
Zhangsan thought Lisi will by you take back self 's home
‘Zhangsan thought Lisi would be taken by you back to his/my/your home.’

The sentences of (73a–b) show that a second person nominal following ba/bei is a possible antecedent for ziji. The nominal following ba/bei, however, does not block reference to the subject of that clause. A first person subordinate subject, however, blocks reference by ziji to the matrix subject. In contrast, in (73c–d), in which the subordinate subject is third person, reference to the matrix subject is possible. This pattern is explained if only subjects result in Blocking (since only subjects occur as the specifier of AGR), but any c-commanding nominal (including the nominals following ba/bei) is a potential antecedent for ziji. 30

The facts of (73) appear to contradict the claim made earlier in this section that the occurrence of a first or second person pronoun anywhere in the sentence will cause a Blocking Effect. In fact, however, a comparison of (73c–d) with (74) shows that a mild Blocking Effect has occurred in (73):

(74)
a. Zhangsani
yiwei Lisij
hui ba Xiao Mingk
dai hui zijii/j/k
de jia.
Zhangsan thought Lisi will BA you take back self 's home
‘Zhangsan thought I would take Xiao Ming back to his/my/your home.’
b. Zhangsani
yiwei Lisij
hui bei Xiao Mingk
dai hui zijii/j/k
de jia.
Zhangsan thought Lisi will by you take back self 's home
‘Zhangsan thought I would be taken by Xiao Ming back to his/my/your home.’

While in (73c–d) it is possible to understand ziji as referring to Zhangsan, this reading is much more salient in (74). That is, a mild Blocking Effect occurs in (73c–d) due to the occurrence of a second person pronoun following ba/bei. The strength of the Blocking, however, is much less than in (73a–b), in which a first person pronoun occurs in subject position. This is precisely the pattern that would be expected if agreement-based Blocking is independent of discourse Blocking. Discourse-based Blocking would result in some degree of Blocking simply because a first or second person pronoun occurs, thereby introducing an external PIVOT to the sentence. Agreement-based Blocking, however, would occur only when there is a change in the person of the subject. Thus, Blocking by subjects should be stronger than Blocking by non-subjects, since in the case of subjects both agreement-based Blocking and discourse-based Blocking occur. In the case of non-subjects, however, only discourse-based Blocking would apply. The pattern just described would have no explanation if all Blocking is due entirely to discourse constraints. Thus, the pattern of Blocking found in ba/bei sentences constitutes an argument that both agreement-based and discourse-based Blocking exist in Chinese.

An additional argument that the Blocking Effect has a grammatical as well as a discourse basis is provided by a close examination of sentences in which a third person subject blocks a first or second person antecedent, as in (75):

(75)
Zhangsani
renwei [woj zhidao [Wangwuk xihuan ziji*i/??j/k]].
Zhangsan think I know Wangwu like self
‘Zhangsan thinks that I know that Wangwu likes himself.’

Let us consider (75) from the perspective of discourse. The presence of wo ‘I’ in (75) is predicted to force the speaker to be the external PIVOT in (75), thereby preventing Zhangsan from being the internal PIVOT. Since only the PIVOT can be the antecedent for LD ziji, it is predicted that the possible antecedents for ziji in (75) are the local subject, Wangwu (since local subjects are not affected by logophoric conditions), or the intermediate subject, wo (since wo is the PIVOT), but not the matrix subject, Zhangsan (which is neither local nor the PIVOT). That is, first and second person are predicted to block third person (since first and second person induce an external PIVOT), but third person is predicted not to block first and second person. 31
It is true that Blocking of first person by third person is somewhat weaker than Blocking of third person by first person, as in (76):

(76)
Zhangsani
renwei [Wangwuj
zhidao [wok
xihuan ziji*i/*j/k]].
Zhangsan think Wangwu know I like self
‘Zhangsan thinks that Wangwu knows that I like myself.’

However, the hypothesis that blocking is due entirely to discourse predicts that reference by ziji to the intermediate subject in (75) would be as well-formed as is reference to the intermediate subject in (1) (repeated here):

(1)
Zhangsani
renwei Lisij
zhidao Wangwuk
xihuan zijii/j/k.
Zhangsan think Lisi know Wangwu like self
‘Zhangsan thinks Lisi knows Wangwu likes self.’
This, however, is not the case; reference to the intermediate subject is worst in (76), bad in (75), and good in (1).

These gradations in well-formedness are not predicted by either the grammatical or the discourse hypothesis alone. If, however, both discourse and grammar play a role in the Blocking Effect, the gradations of well-formedness are predicted correctly: (1) is best because it does not violate either grammatical or discourse restrictions; (75) is somewhat ill-formed because it violates grammatical but not discourse conditions; finally, (76) is worst because it is ill-formed in terms of both grammar and discourse.

We conclude that there is considerable evidence that the Blocking Effect in Chinese is due in part to discourse and in part to grammar. As far as we can tell, the grammatical component in Blocking seems best explained by the agreement theory of Blocking. Thus, we shall now examine whether the agreement theory of Blocking is compatible with the theories of reflexive movement that are under consideration.

The analysis in section 9.3, in which the agreement theory of Blocking was introduced, assumed that reflexives move by head movement and that the final position of the reflexive is the INFL or AGR of the clause containing the antecedent. Thus, the traditional head-movement analysis is fully compatible with the agreement theory of Blocking: the reflexive adjoins to INFL/AGR, and, in those languages in which INFL/AGR is generated without phi-features, the reflexive passes its phi-features to INFL/AGR. If the specifier of INFL/AGR does not agree with INFL/AGR (and, hence, the reflexive) in phi-features the sentence will be ill-formed. Let us turn next to the variant of the movement analysis, the XP-movement analysis, in which the reflexive adjoins to IP rather than to INFL/ AGR. In this analysis the reflexive is not adjoined to INFL/AGR, so it is not immediately apparent why the phi-features of the reflexive should be passed to INFL/AGR. Thus, it might appear that XP-movement fails to predict the grammatical component in Blocking. Let us assume, however, that the Feature Percolation Principles ((50), repeated here) assumed for head movement also apply in the case of XP-movement:
(50) The Feature Percolation Principles (FPP):

row.entry: The features of the mother node and the features of the daughter nodes will be identical.
If the features of the daughter nodes conflict, the mother node will have the features of the head node.

subsection.p: According to (50), if a reflexive with the feature [+3] is adjoined to IP, the feature [+3] will be passed on to all projections of I unless I has features that conflict with [+3]. Thus, on the assumption that the reflexive is adjoined to the projection-bearing agreement (IP or AGRP), the XP-movement analysis makes the same predictions as the head-movement analysis. Both variants of movement appear to make correct predictions regarding the grammatical component of the Blocking Effect.

To summarize, in all the three areas considered, the two variants of the movement approach appear to be equally adequate. Under different assumptions, both head movement and XP movement are able to predict that long-distance reflexives are monomorphemic and (strictly) local reflexives complex. With regard to subject orientation, head movement and XP movement make the same predictions. The determining factor with regard to subject orientation is whether movement is movement to an initial position in the clause subordinate to that containing the antecedent, or movement to a position in the cause containing the antecedent. Finally, the grammatical component of the Blocking Effect is correctly predicted by both variants of movement. We conclude that movement theories of long-distance reflexives appear to capture well the core typological properties of long-distance reflexives. The facts that distinguish between the two variants on movement appear to be quite subtle in nature, and in the few cases in which there are differential predictions, the predictions are due primarily to subsidiary assumptions. Thus, we conclude that the evidence does not allow a clear decision regarding which variant of movement is to be preferred.

subsection.heading: 10.5 Long-distance reflexives in islands
subsection.p: We have shown in section 10.4 that movement analyses appear to make a number of desirable predictions regarding bound anaphor long-distance reflexives. There is, however, a serious problem with the movement analyses. An LF-movement analysis predicts that LD reflexives should not be grammatical in environments out of which movement is blocked. Thus, LD reflexives are predicted not to occur in syntactic islands (Ross 1986, inter alia), but such sentences are well-formed:
(77) Ziji within the relative clause:

row.entry: ‘Zhangsan thinks Wangwu saw the person who dislikes him/himself (Zhangsan, Wangwu or the person).’

subsection.p: (78) Ziji within the adjunct clause:

row.entry: ‘Zhangsan thinks that Wangwu said that if Lisi criticized him/himself (Wangwu, Lisi or Zhangsan), then he won't go.’

subsection.p: The structure of (77–78) is roughly that of (79–80) or (81–82), depending on which variant of the movement analysis is chosen (the island structure is shown in boldface):
(79) LF structure of ziji within the relative clause (head movement):

row.entry: ‘Zhangsan thinks Wangwu saw the person who dislikes him/himself (Zhangsan, Wangwu or the person).’

subsection.p: (80) LF structure of ziji within the adjunct clause (head movement):

row.entry: ‘Zhangsan thinks that Wangwu said that if Lisi criticized him/himself (Wangwu, Lisi or Zhangsan), then he won't go.’

subsection.p: (81) LF structure of ziji within the relative clause (XP movement):

row.entry: ‘Zhangsan thinks Wangwu saw the person who dislikes him/himself (Zhangsan, Wangwu or the person).’

subsection.p: (82) LF structure of ziji within the adjunct clause (XP movement):

row.entry: ‘Zhangsan thinks that Wangwu said that if Lisi criticized him/himself (Wangwu, Lisi or Zhangsan), then he won't go.’

subsection.p: In (79–82) the reflexive moves out of a modifying or adjunct clause, a movement that violates Subjacency or the Constraint on Extraction Domains (or contemporary analogues), and which thus would be predicted to result in ungrammaticality.

Explanations for such violations of island constraints have been proposed for both head movement and XP movement. For example, Huang and Tang (1991) argue that this pattern of island violation by XP movement in LF is in fact not surprising, given what we know about the syntax of wh-in-situ. Since Huang (1982b), it has been well known that argument wh-phrases in situ do not exhibit Subjacency or CED effects (although adjunct wh-phrases do). This is true both of normal wh-questions in Chinese-type languages and of multiple questions in English-type languages. Thus, in Chinese it is possible to ask a question about an argument within a relative clause or an adjunct, as shown in (83–84); and in English a direct multiple question may have one (more) of its wh-phrases located within such an island, as shown in (85–86):

(83)
Ni zui xihuan [shei xie de shu]?
you most like who write DE Book
‘You like the books that who wrote most?’

(84)
Ni shi zai [shei lai-le yihou] cai zou de?
you be at who came after then leave Prt
‘You left after who had come?’
(85) Who bought the books who wrote?
(86) Who left after who arrived?

Given the pattern exhibited by (83–86), the island violations described in (81–82) in fact come as no surprise. In all these cases, LF movement affects an argument. A wh-in-situ in argument position seems to exhibit no LF island effects, so an LD reflexive, also an operator occurring in argument position, also exhibits no LF island effects. In other words, given the facts of (83–86) as they are, the facts of the LD reflexive represented by (81–82) present no new empirical problem, and no surprise. Whatever explains the well-formedness of (83–86) can also explain the well-formedness of (81–82).

Of course, the facts of (83–86) themselves pose a theoretical problem, as to why covert extraction of arguments in LF should differ from overt extraction in Syntax. This question is addressed in Fiengo et al. (1988), where it is argued, on the basis of the Barriers system, that the observed island violations shown in (83–86) are only apparent violations. In line with the Barriers framework, Fiengo et al. assumed (i) that IP adjunction is not available in overt Syntax but available in LF, where QR, an IP adjunction operation, applies; (ii) that adjunction of α to a category &bgr; has the effect of ‘debarrierizing’ the boundary of &bgr;; 32 and (iii) that wh-in-situ phrases are both quantifiers and interrogative phrases: they move first qua quantifiers by successive-cyclic adjunction and then qua interrogatives by substitution into Spec, CP. Given the availability of IP adjunction, it is in fact a consequence of the Barriers system that wh-in-situ may escape the effects of island constraints, since all island barriers may be voided by the adjunction operation. That is, the island violations are only apparent; given the possibility of successive adjunction, no island effects are visible at all.

Huang and Tang (1991) proposed that the fact that LD reflexives do not exhibit island effects simply follows from the Barriers system as explicated by Fiengo et al. (1988), under the assumption that the bare reflexives are operators that undergo IP adjunction in LF, on a par with argument wh-phrases in situ (which involve an additional step of movement into Spec, CP). The availability of LD binding in (81–82) comes about because ziji could move out of a relative clause or adjunct island by successive cyclic adjunction. The following illustrates successive cyclic adjunction out of a relative clause:
Although covert argument extraction in general does not display island effects, it has also been well known that covert adjunct extraction does so:
(88) Wh-extraction of adjuncts out of islands:

row.entry: ‘Though Lisi didn't come why, you weren't angry?’
‘You like the book that he bought why?’

subsection.p: To account for the argument–adjunct asymmetries of this sort and other related facts, it was proposed by Huang (1982b) that while Subjacency/CED obtains only in overt syntax, the Empty Category Principle obtains in both overt Syntax and LF. Recall that the successive-cyclic adjunction hypothesis was used to explain the lack of covert Subjacency/CED effects by showing that, given the availability of successive-cyclic adjunction through IP in LF, such island effects are in principle invisible. The question now arises why, given the availability of successive-cyclic adjunction, covert adjunct extraction still displays clear ECP effects.

In order to solve this problem, Fiengo et al. (1988) suggested that adjunction to a maximal projection debarrierizes that projection only for Subjacency, but not for Government. Therefore, the extraction of arguments out of islands will be predicted to be well-formed since arguments are always lexically governed (or theta-governed). In contrast, the extraction of adjuncts will result in a violation of proper Government, since the adjunction node blocks proper Government from the outside.

As indicated in note 32, the idea is that adjunction debarrierizes a barrier by breaking a barrier into two segments, thus allowing an item to cross one segment at a time out of the barrier. Fiengo et al.'s proposal amounts to saying that, while a segment of a barrier is not enough to block movement, it is strong enough to block proper Government. This is not an unreasonable assumption since there is independent evidence that Government is blocked by ‘weak barriers’. For example, a negative phrase does not create a Subjacency barrier, but does count as a barrier for ECP (Ross's 1986 ‘inner islands’; also Rizzi 1990b). Furthermore, complements to factive or non-bridge verbs must count as barriers for ECP:

(89)
a. This book, which you like, has won the Pulitzer Prize.
b. This book, which you don't like, has won the Pulitzer Prize.

(90)
a. This book, as you know, has won the Pulitzer Prize.
b. *This book, as you don't know, has won the Pulitzer Prize.

(91)
a. What did you regret that John had stolen?
b. *Why did you regret that [John had stolen the key t]?

(92)
a. What prize did John whine that he never got?
b. *Why did John whine that [he never got that prize t]?

Although this approach to (apparent) island violations of the LD reflexives seemed satisfactory given the set of assumptions made in the Barriers framework, it is ultimately called into question because the Barriers framework depends on stipulations some of which seem entirely unexplained. For example, while the Barriers system allows covert IP adjunction (to allow for QR and similar processes), it specifically prohibits IP adjunction in overt syntax. This is necessary for the system to work, as Chomsky (1986b) notes, or most island effects would not be derived at all. For example, if IP adjunction were allowed in overt syntax, (overt) movement out of a complex NP would be licit – as shown in (93) and (94) – an incorrect result:
(93) *Mary, Tom saw the man who criticized t.

In other words, the Barriers system must include arbitrary stipulations in order for it to work in overt syntax, and at the same time not include such stipulations for it to work in covert syntax. Such undesirable stipulations undercut the fundamental assumptions of current Minimalist thinking. Thus, this account of why LD reflexives are possible in islands seems untenable.

An approach to this problem within the context of the head-movement analysis was proposed by Sung and Cole (1991). Sung and Cole argue that head movement can provide an account of the island facts if more complex structures are adopted for Chinese, based on Tang (1990). Tang proposed that Chinese relative clauses have the following structure:
(95) Tang's structure for the Chinese noun phrase:

According to Sung and Cole, given Tang's proposed structure for the Chinese relative clause, with slight modification in the assumptions made in Barriers (Chomsky 1986b), relative clauses and adjunct clauses will be predicted not to be islands for head movement but to be islands for XP movement:

li.p: In order for a head to L-mark a maximal projection, it must: (i) be a lexical rather than a functional head; and (ii) govern the maximal projection.

subsection.p: Let us consider the application of head movement to a reflexive inside an adjunct clause:

Per (97), the movement of ziji to C2 will make C lexical. This will also cause C2 to L-mark CP3. Thus, the extraction of ziji will be well-formed. The assumptions in (88) will not allow the extraction of an adjunct XP from an adjunct. This is because an XP cannot move to C2 and void the islandhood of CP3. Thus, given (97), head movement makes the correct predictions regarding extraction from adjuncts.
We shall turn next to reflexives in relative clauses:

(98)
a. Predeterminer relative clause in Chinese:
ec lai zheli de nage ren
come here REL that man
‘the man that came here’
b. Postdeterminer relative clause in Chinese:
nage ec lai zheli de ren
that come here REL man
‘the man that came here’
In (99a–b) the CP is governed by a functional head: K in the case of (99a) and Cl in the case of (99b):

(99)
a. Zhangsan bu xihuan bu xihuan ziji de nage ren.
Zhangsa not like not like self REL that man
‘Zhangsan does not like the man who does not like him/himself.’
b. Zhangsan bu xihuan nage bu xihuan ziji de ren.
Zhangsa not like that not like self REL man
‘Zhangsan does not like the man who does not like him/himself.’

In (100a–b) the modifying clause is governed by a functional category: K in the case of (100a) and Cl in the case of (100b). Thus, if ziji moves by head movement to K or Cl, the governing functional category will thereby become lexical and CP will cease to be a barrier: in both (100a) and (100b) the movement of ziji to the functional category governing the modifying CP makes that functional category lexical, and thereby debarrierizes the CP. But the movement of an XP from a modifying clause would not have that effect, since an XP could never move to an X0 position. Thus, while adjunct and relative clause CPs are predicted not to be barriers for head movement, they are predicted to be barriers for XP movement.

The account just described, like that proposed for XP movement, suffers from both empirical and theoretical defects. From an empirical perspective, it makes the prediction that the existence of an LD reflexive inside an island enables other elements to move out of the island. This is so, because once ziji head-moves to I and L-marks the island, the island ceases to be an island for the movement of other categories as well. But this prediction is clearly incorrect for either overt movements (as in (101)) or covert movements (as in (102)):

(101)
*Lisi, Zhangsan bu xihuan [t song-gei ziji de shu].
Lisi Zhangsan not like [t gave self DE book]
‘*Lisii Zhangsanj does not like the books that [ti gave to selfj].’

(102)
*Zhangsan, bu xihuan [weishenme piping ziji de ren].
Zhangsan not like [why criticize self DE person]
‘*For what reason x, Zhangsanj does not like the person who criticized selfj for x.’

Specifically, the account predicts that these sentences would be grammatical just in case the reflexive is bound LD by Zhangsan, but not if it is locally bound. But this prediction is not fulfilled. It should be noted, however, that this objection may not hold if the L-marking of the island is viewed as applying only at the stage of the derivation when the moved head governs the island, and not at subsequent stages in the derivation when the reflexive has moved on to its ultimate target. On this view ziji debarrierizes the island for itself but not for subsequent movement.

More generally, this account suggests that head movement should, in general, be possible from inside islands, but in fact, with the exception of LD reflexives, head movement is very local in nature. For instance, verbal inflection from one clause does not move by head movement onto the verb of a higher clause. Thus, an account that allows heads the freedom to move irrespective of barriers that affect XP movement would seem to make precisely the wrong claim for all putative head-movement constructions other than reflexive movement. With respect to theory, the account just proposed is based on the assumption, taken from Barriers, that islandhood is due to movement across an un-L-marked node. However, the notion of L-marking, based on Government, seems quite antithetical to the fundamental assumptions of Minimalism. Thus, this explanation for the occurrence of LD reflexives in islands seems implausible.

We have argued at some length that two seemingly plausible explanations for the occurrence of LD reflexives in islands are both inadequate. We therefore conclude, that the fact that reflexives can occur in islands continues to pose non-trivial theoretical questions as to their explanation. To conclude this section, we have shown that while movement has important advantages over other analyses of long-distance reflexives, the analysis suffers from the absence of a satisfactory explanation of the occurrence of reflexives in islands. This suggests that a new analysis is needed, one which has the advantage of predicting correctly the core typological characteristics of LD reflexives and which is compatible with, or predicted by, an optimal theory of movement and constraints.

subsection.heading: 11 Conclusion: economy and long-distance reflexives
subsection.p: We would like to end this chapter by examining the ways in which the facts described in previous sections might contribute to our understanding of how long-distance reflexives fit into the anaphoric possibilities for natural language. We have seen that there appear to exist three kinds of entities which might be considered ‘long-distance reflexives’ in a pre-theoretical sense: long-distance bound anaphors, forms which are indeterminate between local reflexives and pronouns, and reflexives which undergo ‘conversion’ from bound anaphor to pronominal in specific syntactic and pragmatic contexts. Reuland (2001; and see chapter 33) discusses two types of reflexives (local reflexives and those that have undergone ‘logophoric conversion’ to pronominals), and notes that they are in complementary distribution: local reflexives undergo ‘conversion’ to pronominals when (i) anaphoric binding is blocked in the syntax and (ii) they satisfy certain logophoric conditions. This distribution suggests that local reflexives are given pronominal interpretation only if, given the specific syntactic properties of the language in question, they lack an eligible local antecedent as bound anaphors (e.g., per Reuland, Binding is blocked by subjunctive mood in Icelandic). That is, the complementarity derives from a principle of Avoid Pronoun, which requires that a form which is inherently capable of interpretation as either a pronominal (i.e., by coreference) or an anaphor (by Binding) must receive interpretation as a bound anaphor in contexts where an anaphoric interpretation is possible.

Why might such a preference for anaphoric interpretation exist? Reuland argues that the complementarity can be explained if we assume that local reflexives constitute a chain, a single syntactic object, perhaps as a result of movement of the reflexive. Reuland proposes that interpretation in which syntax and semantics work in tandem (i.e., by chain formation, in which a Binding relationship is forced by the existence of the chain) is inherently ‘cheaper’ than interpretation by coreference (in which real-world information plays a role in the interpretive process). 33 Thus, whenever a single form can either form a chain (and, hence, receive a bound anaphor interpretation) or be interpreted pronominally, the possibility of the more economical chain interpretation should eliminate the possibility of pronominal interpretation. Pronominal interpretation should occur only when, for some reason, chain formation is blocked. 34

We would like to extend this proposal from local reflexives to bound anaphor long-distance reflexives. Let us assume that this type of long-distance reflexive is derived by movement, putting aside the problems discussed in section 10.5. (We also abstract away from the issue of whether the movement is head movement or phrasal movement, whether it is adjunction to IP or to AGR, and what drives the movement.) If bound anaphor long-distance reflexives are derived by movement, chain formation must also occur in the case of bound anaphor long-distance reflexives. This predicts that in languages in which long-distance chain formation is possible, a c-command relationship would hold between the reflexive and its antecedent, and the reflexive would receive a sloppy rather than a strict interpretation under ellipsis. This extension of Reuland's analysis would predict that only when chain formation is somehow blocked would a pronominal interpretation become possible. This prediction appears to be correct, at least with respect to Chinese. As was pointed out by Yu (1992, 1996) and others, when ziji is unbound syntactically it receives a pronominal interpretation which is subject to logophoric requirements:

(103)
Bu qinchu ziji shenme shihou neng qu Meiguo niansu; Xiao Li ye zheme juede.
not clear self when can go US read.book Little Li also thus feel
‘It is not clear when I can go to the US to study. Little Li feels the same way.’

In (103) there is no syntactic binder for ziji. As predicted, the absence of a syntactic binder allows ziji to receive a pronominal interpretation, as is shown by the fact that the elliptical clause can receive either a strict or a sloppy interpretation (‘Xiao Li says it is unclear when I can go’ or ‘Xiao Li says it is unclear when he can go’). Thus, Reuland's theory of economy, together with the movement theory of bound anaphor long-distance reflexives, predicts that both local and bound anaphor long-distance reflexives will be able to receive a pronominal interpretation only when there is no syntactic binder available.

We will next examine the predictions of Reuland's analysis with regard to long-distance reflexives like those in Malay and Turkish, forms that are interpreted as pronominals when they are long distance. Are such forms counter-examples to Reuland's theory of economy? In the context of Reuland's theory, the fact that such forms have the properties of pronominals rather than bound anaphors tells us that, unlike the case with bound anaphor long-distance reflexives, chain formation must be impossible. There is, in fact, evidence with respect to local uses of Malay dirinya that chain formation has failed to apply. Example (5a) (repeated here) shows that even in a local context c-command is not required for dirinya:

(5)
a. [NP Bapa Sitij]i
tidakk
suka dirinyai/j/k.
father Siti not like self.3sg
‘Siti's father does not like her/himself/him.’

Examples with dirinya are to be contrasted with the complex reflexive dirinya sendiri, which requires a local antecedent and which is ill-formed when the potential antecedent does not stand in a c-command relation to the reflexive:

(104)
[NP Ibu Alij]i
telah menyiram air di dirinya sendirii/*j.
mother Ali already splash water on self.3sg alone
‘Ali's mother already splashed water onto herself.’

We therefore conclude that dirinya, unlike dirinya sendiri, cannot participate in chain formation. 35 Since chain formation is blocked with this form, there will not be competition between pronominal and anaphoric dirinya. Thus it is expected that apparent long-distance reflexives employing forms like dirinya will have the distribution of a pronominal rather than that of a bound anaphor.

We have shown that an extension of Reuland's analysis successfully predicts the syntactic properties of each type of apparent long-distance reflexive. We will turn now to the discourse properties. We will start with bound anaphor long-distance reflexives. These have been argued to consist of chains between the surface site of the anaphor and a position in which a c-commanding antecedent is located within the local domain (roughly, the governing category) of the reflexive. Such a chain may be long distance (inter-clausal) when otherwise permitted by the structure of the language and by principles of Universal Grammar (such as principles of chain formation). 36 The problem raised by discourse for this analysis is why logophoric conditions might apply to the relationship between the head of the chain and the antecedent, with variation from language to language. We would like to suggest that the answer may be provided by viewing the chain as uninterpretable unless it is related to an antecedent by a predication relation along the lines suggested in Huang and Liu (2000). While a variety of technical problems remains unsolved with respect to this proposal, we propose that discourse principles, which may vary from language to language, determine whether the predication relationship would be subject to logophoric requirements. Thus, in the case of bound anaphor long-distance reflexives, logophoricity may restrict the relationship between the chain and the ultimate antecedent. However, the relationship between the head and tail of the chain would be a syntactic relation which would not be subject to logophoric requirements. In Huang and Liu's terms, predication of a chain structure on the ultimate antecedent establishes a relation at the interface level between syntax and discourse. It is then natural that such a mediation process is subject to both discourse and syntactic restrictions. But the relation between elements internal to a chain structure would be strictly syntactic, not subject to extra-sentential considerations.

We turn next to those reflexives which can be used long distance only when they lack a c-commanding antecedent in their local domain (e.g., English and Icelandic subjunctives). Why are such reflexives obligatorily subject to logophoric requirements when logophoric requirements are optional in the case of movement chains (predication, according to Huang and Liu) and absent entirely in the case of the Malay/Turkish type of reflexive, in which chain formation is blocked? Reuland proposes that the answer can be found by examining the fundamental semantic content of pronouns. The semantic contribution of pronouns is to express orientation vis-à-vis the speech act (speaker, perceiver). This orientation is the lexical content of personal pronouns like I and you. In the case of anaphors that undergo ‘conversion’ to pronominals, orientation is not lexically specified, since these forms are radically deficient in lexical content. While ‘classical’ personal pronouns express only speech-act orientation, ‘de-anaphoric’ pronouns lack even that lexical content. In order to be well-formed, they must take their orientation from the context. That is, they must satisfy conditions of logophoricity.

Turning, finally, to ‘pronominal’ long-distance reflexives like those found in Malay and Turkish, Reuland's theory would predict that, unlike sig, they must include a specification of orientation in their lexical content, as must third person personal pronouns. It is not immediately apparent how the specification of orientation could be demonstrated without circularity, so we will leave this question open for future discussion.

We would like to emphasize that the syntactic environments making possible a free interpretation of anaphoric forms may be quite different cross-linguistically. As was pointed out to us by Eric Reuland, whereas in English the relevant condition is whether the anaphor is a syntactic argument of a predicate, in Icelandic the crucial factor is whether sig is in the domain of a subjunctive verb. As discussed in Reuland (2001; see also chapter 33) and Cole et al. (2001a), the crucial factor is whether something prevents the anaphor from being hooked up to its antecedent by a syntactic process. In Icelandic, this is the blocking of chain linking by the subjunctive. In English, this could be, according to Reinhart and Reuland (1991), the impossibility for SELF to covertly move to the predicate from a non-argument position. (Of course, to obtain well-formedness, appropriate discourse requirements must be met as well.)
8 There seems not to be any way to construct an analogous test sentence in the case of (12a).

9 It is not important for us that the pronominal reflexive is literally ‘converted’ from the anaphoric reflexive by a process of derivational morphology. We shall use this term simply to mean that the pronominal use of the reflexive is somehow specified as ‘marked’ or ‘secondary’.

15 In some cases it is not clear whether a form is a bound anaphor reflexive or a pronominal. The string ta ziji in Mandarin appears to be ambiguous between a local bound anaphor and a pronoun ta modified by an emphatic reflexive ziji. Thus, Tang (1985, 1989), Sung (1990), and others have argued that all instances of apparent long-distance ta ziji are in fact instances of the pronoun ta modified by an emphatic reflexive rather than a complex anaphor. It must be recognized, however, that there are no completely convincing syntactic tests that demonstrate that all cases of apparent long-distance ta ziji are really the pronoun ta modified by ziji.

subsection.p: One argument in favor of the proposal that long-distance ta ziji involves pronominal ta is found in Cole et al. (2004), published in Chinese, which shows that long-distance ta ziji (and its Teochew counterpart i kaki) manifest the discourse conditions of the personal pronouns ta and i, and not those of the long-distance reflexives ziji and kaki: while ziji and kaki are subject to various logophoric conditions (see Cole et al. 2001b), no such conditions apply to long-distance ta ziji and i kaki. This state of affairs would be expected if ta ziji and i kaki are really the third person pronoun modified by an intensive reflexive, but not if they are bound anaphor long-distance reflexives. (Similar considerations apparently hold for Cantonese as well.)

31 This is similar to the predictions made earlier by Pan (1995, 1997, 2001), who bases his predictions on a variant of the de se hypothesis.

32 See Chomsky (1986b) for more details. Adjunction of α to &bgr; has the effect of splitting the node &bgr; into two ‘segments’ with &bgr; now located between the two segments: [&bgr; α [&bgr; . . . tα . . . ]]. Thus, by adjoining itself to &bgr;, α crosses one half of the boundary of &bgr; (the lower segment [&bgr;). Now, if α is moved out further, it will cross the other half (the higher segment [&bgr;). In this way, by adjunction to &bgr;, α may get out of the boundary of &bgr;, not by crossing the entire boundary of &bgr; at once, but by crossing one segment at a time.

33 Reuland phrases his account in terms of cross-modular operations. A syntactic chain requires only two cross-modular operations while coreference requires four. See Reuland (2001) for the details of how the evaluation is conducted.
34 There is a point of similarity here with Pollard and Xue (2001), who propose that reflexives are interpreted on discourse/pragmatic considerations once they are not ‘bound’ syntactically.

35 Reuland speculates that number plays a critical role in determining whether a form is able to undergo chain formation, and, hence, show the distribution of a bound anaphor. Dirinya appears to be a counter-example to the proposal that number is the only feature that could block chain formation: while the reflexive root diri- is inflected for person, inflection for number is not possible.

subsection.p: It should be noted that number appears to distinguish diri- from personal pronouns. In the pronominal system it is possible to distinguish dia ‘3p pronoun’ (singular or plural) from mereka or diaorang ‘3ppl pronoun’ (obligatorily plural). No such distinction exists for diri-: the only possible form is diri-nya ‘3p’, and number cannot be indicated.

We have seen, however, that dirinya does not permit chain formation. Thus, it cannot be the presence or absence of number which is critical for distinguishing between forms that allow chain formation and those that do not.

p.span: 36 That is, long-distance chains would be permitted when the reflexive is monomorphemic and when no domain restrictions block the chain. For instance, in Icelandic a finite clause boundary would block chain formation.
